					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Apple Inc.</span></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 148 languages"   >
	<label id="p-lang-btn-label" for="p-lang-btn-checkbox" class="vector-dropdown-label cdx-button cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--weight-quiet cdx-button--action-progressive mw-portlet-lang-heading-148" aria-hidden="true"  ><span class="vector-icon mw-ui-icon-language-progressive mw-ui-icon-wikimedia-language-progressive"></span>

<span class="vector-dropdown-label-text">148 languages</span>
	</label>
	<div class="vector-dropdown-content">

		<div class="vector-menu-content">
			
			<ul class="vector-menu-content-list">
				
				<li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-af badge-Q17437796 badge-featuredarticle mw-list-item" title="featured article badge"><a href="https://af.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc. – 					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">American multinational technology company</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"Apple (company)" redirects here. For other companies with the same name, see <a href="/wiki/Apple_(disambiguation)#Businesses_and_organisations" class="mw-disambig" title="Apple (disambiguation)">Apple (disambiguation) §&#160;Businesses and organisations</a>.</div>

srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300" /></span></span> <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$62.15</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>billion&#160;(2023)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="padding-right: 0.5em;"><div style="display: inline-block; line-height: 1.2em; padding: .1em 0;">Number of employees</div></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height: 1.35em;">161,000&#160;(2023)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="padding-right: 0.5em;"><a href="/wiki/Subsidiary" title="Subsidiary">Subsidiaries</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height: 1.35em;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Apple_Studios" href="/wiki/Braeburn_Capital" title="Braeburn Capital">Braeburn Capital</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Claris" title="Claris">Claris</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Drive.ai" class="infobox-full-data" style="line-height: 1.35em;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1218072481"></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1215172403">.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free.id-lock-free a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}body:not(.skin-timeless):not(.skin-minerva) a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}body:not(.skin-timeless):not(.skin-minerva) .mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription .cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#2C882D;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{color:#18911F}html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error,html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{color:#f8a397}@media(prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error,html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{color:#f8a397}html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{color:#18911F}}</style><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://bgp.tools/as/714">714</a></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="padding-right: 0.5em;">Website</th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height: 1.35em;"><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://apple.com">apple<wbr />.com</a></span></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-below" style="line-height: 1.35em;"><b>Footnotes&#160;/&#32;references</b><br /><sup id="cite_ref-Apple-10-K-Report-2023_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-10-K-Report-2023-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Apple Inc.</b> (formerly <b>Apple Computer, Inc.</b>) is an American <a href="/wiki/Multinational_corporation" title="Multinational corporation">multinational corporation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Technology_company" title="Technology company">technology company</a> headquartered in <a href="/wiki/Cupertino,_California" title="Cupertino, California">Cupertino, California</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a>. It <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc._design_motifs" title="Apple Inc. design motifs">designs</a>, develops, and sells <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">consumer electronics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Computer_software" class="mw-redirect" title="Computer software">computer software</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Online_service" class="mw-redirect" title="Online service">online services</a>. <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Apple_Inc._products" class="mw-redirect" title="Timeline of Apple Inc. products">Devices</a> include the <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPad" title="IPad">iPad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mac_(computer)" title="Mac (computer)">Mac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch" title="Apple Watch">Apple Watch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vision_Pro" class="mw-redirect" title="Vision Pro">Vision Pro</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV" title="Apple TV">Apple TV</a>; <a href="/wiki/List_of_Apple_operating_systems" title="List of Apple operating systems">operating systems</a> include <a href="/wiki/IOS" title="IOS">iOS</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPadOS" title="IPadOS">iPadOS</a>, and <a href="/wiki/MacOS" title="MacOS">macOS</a>; and software applications and services include <a href="/wiki/ITunes" title="ITunes">iTunes</a>, <a href="/wiki/ICloud" title="ICloud">iCloud</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Music" title="Apple Music">Apple Music</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV%2B" title="Apple TV+">Apple TV+</a>.
</p><p>For most of 2011 to 2024, Apple became the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization" title="List of public corporations by market capitalization">largest company by market capitalization</a> until <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a> assumed the position in January 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:4_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> In 2022, Apple was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_technology_companies_by_revenue" title="List of largest technology companies by revenue">largest technology company by revenue</a>, with <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$394.3</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>billion.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (March 2024)">failed verification</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> As of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Apple was the fourth-largest <a href="/wiki/Market_share_of_personal_computer_vendors" title="Market share of personal computer vendors">personal computer vendor by unit sales</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-2023_PC_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2023_PC-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_manufacturing_companies_by_revenue" title="List of largest manufacturing companies by revenue">largest manufacturing company by revenue</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_mobile_phones#2023" title="List of best-selling mobile phones">largest vendor of mobile phones</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> It is one of the <a href="/wiki/Big_Tech" title="Big Tech">Big Five</a> American <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a> companies, alongside <a href="/wiki/Alphabet_Inc." title="Alphabet Inc.">Alphabet</a> (the parent company of <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>), <a href="/wiki/Amazon_(company)" title="Amazon (company)">Amazon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Meta_Platforms" title="Meta Platforms">Meta</a> (the parent company of <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>.
</p><p>Apple was founded as Apple Computer Company on April 1, 1976, to produce and market <a href="/wiki/Steve_Wozniak" title="Steve Wozniak">Steve Wozniak</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Apple_I" title="Apple I">Apple I</a> personal computer. The company was incorporated by Wozniak and <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a> in 1977. Its second computer, the <a href="/wiki/Apple_II" title="Apple II">Apple II</a>, became a best seller as one of the first mass-produced <a href="/wiki/Microcomputers" class="mw-redirect" title="Microcomputers">microcomputers</a>. Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Lisa" title="Apple Lisa">Lisa</a> in 1983 and the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_128K" title="Macintosh 128K">Macintosh</a> in 1984, as some of the first computers to use a <a href="/wiki/Graphical_user_interface" title="Graphical user interface">graphical user interface</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Computer_mouse" title="Computer mouse">mouse</a>. By 1985, the company's internal problems included the high cost of its products and power struggles between executives. That year Jobs left Apple to form <a href="/wiki/NeXT,_Inc." class="mw-redirect" title="NeXT, Inc.">NeXT, Inc.</a>, and Wozniak withdrew to other ventures. The market for personal computers expanded and evolved throughout the 1990s, and Apple lost considerable <a href="/wiki/Market_share" title="Market share">market share</a> to the lower-priced <a href="/wiki/Wintel" title="Wintel">Wintel</a> duopoly of the <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows" title="Microsoft Windows">Microsoft Windows</a> operating system on <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a>-powered <a href="/wiki/PC_clones" class="mw-redirect" title="PC clones">PC clones</a>.
</p><p>In 1997, Apple was weeks away from bankruptcy. To resolve its failed <a href="/wiki/Operating_system" title="Operating system">operating system</a> strategy and entice Jobs's return, it bought NeXT. Over the next decade, Jobs guided Apple back to profitability through several tactics including introducing the <a href="/wiki/IMac" title="IMac">iMac</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPod" title="IPod">iPod</a>, iPhone, and iPad to critical acclaim, launching the "<a href="/wiki/Think_different" title="Think different">Think different</a>" campaign and other memorable advertising campaigns, opening the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store" title="Apple Store">Apple Store</a> retail chain, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_mergers_and_acquisitions_by_Apple" title="List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple">acquiring numerous companies</a> to broaden its product portfolio. Jobs resigned in 2011 for health reasons, and died two months later. He was succeeded as CEO by <a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a>.
</p><p>Apple has received criticism regarding its contractors' labor practices, its environmental practices, and its business ethics, including <a href="/wiki/Anti-competitive_practices" title="Anti-competitive practices">anti-competitive practices</a> and materials sourcing. Nevertheless, it has <a href="/wiki/Apple_community" title="Apple community">a large following</a> and a high level of <a href="/wiki/Brand_loyalty" title="Brand loyalty">brand loyalty</a>. It has been consistently ranked as one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_most_valuable_brands" title="List of most valuable brands">most valuable brands</a>.
</p><p>Apple became the first publicly traded U.S. company to be <a href="/wiki/Trillion-dollar_company" class="mw-redirect" title="Trillion-dollar company">valued at over $1&#160;trillion</a> in August 2018, then at $2&#160;trillion in August 2020, and at $3&#160;trillion in January 2022. In June 2023, it was valued at just over $3&#160;trillion.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Apple_Inc." title="History of Apple Inc.">History of Apple Inc.</a></div>
<h3><span id="1976.E2.80.931980:_Founding_and_incorporation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1976–1980:_Founding_and_incorporation">1976–1980: Founding and incorporation</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Apple_Inc.#1971–1985:_Jobs_and_Wozniak" title="History of Apple Inc.">History of Apple Inc. §&#160;1971–1985: Jobs and Wozniak</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Garage.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Apple_Garage.jpg/220px-Apple_Garage.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Apple_Garage.jpg/330px-Apple_Garage.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Apple_Garage.jpg/440px-Apple_Garage.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1365" /></a><figcaption>In 1976, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Steve_Wozniak" title="Steve Wozniak">Steve Wozniak</a> co-founded Apple in Jobs's parents' home on Crist Drive in <a href="/wiki/Los_Altos,_California" title="Los Altos, California">Los Altos, California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046–8_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046–8-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> Wozniak called the popular belief that the company was founded in the garage "a bit of a myth",<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> although they moved some operations to the garage when the bedroom became too crowded.<sup id="cite_ref-Linzmayer01_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Linzmayer01-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:2019-08-04_Apple_I_computer.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/2019-08-04_Apple_I_computer.jpg/220px-2019-08-04_Apple_I_computer.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="161" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/2019-08-04_Apple_I_computer.jpg/330px-2019-08-04_Apple_I_computer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/2019-08-04_Apple_I_computer.jpg/440px-2019-08-04_Apple_I_computer.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4733" data-file-height="3456" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Apple_I" title="Apple I">Apple I</a> is Apple's first product, designed by Wozniak and sold as an assembled circuit board without the required keyboard, monitor, power supply, and the optional case.</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_II_Plus,_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Apple_II_Plus%2C_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg/220px-Apple_II_Plus%2C_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Apple_II_Plus%2C_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg/330px-Apple_II_Plus%2C_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Apple_II_Plus%2C_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg/440px-Apple_II_Plus%2C_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2588" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Apple_II_Plus" title="Apple II Plus">Apple II Plus</a> was introduced in 1979, designed primarily by Wozniak.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Apple Computer Company was founded on April 1, 1976, by <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Wozniak" title="Steve Wozniak">Steve Wozniak</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Wayne" title="Ronald Wayne">Ronald Wayne</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Partnership" title="Partnership">partnership</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046–8_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046–8-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> The company's first product is the <a href="/wiki/Apple_I" title="Apple I">Apple I</a>, a computer designed and hand-built entirely by Wozniak.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> To finance its creation, Jobs sold his <a href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Type_2" title="Volkswagen Type 2">Volkswagen Bus</a>, and Wozniak sold his <a href="/wiki/HP-65" title="HP-65">HP-65</a> calculator.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 57">&#58;&#8202;57&#8202;</span></sup> Neither received the full selling price but in total earned <span style="white-space: nowrap">$1,300</span>&#32;(equivalent to $7,000 in 2023). Wozniak debuted the first prototype <span class="nowrap">Apple I</span> at the <a href="/wiki/Homebrew_Computer_Club" title="Homebrew Computer Club">Homebrew Computer Club</a> in July 1976.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> The Apple I was sold as a <a href="/wiki/Motherboard" title="Motherboard">motherboard</a> with <a href="/wiki/Central_processing_unit" title="Central processing unit">CPU</a>, <a href="/wiki/Random-access_memory" title="Random-access memory">RAM</a>, and basic textual-video chips—a base kit concept which was not yet marketed as a complete personal computer.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> It was priced soon after debut for <span style="white-space: nowrap">$666.66</span>&#32;(equivalent to $3,600 in 2023).<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-iWoz_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iWoz-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 180">&#58;&#8202;180&#8202;</span></sup> Wozniak later said he was unaware of the coincidental <a href="/wiki/Mark_of_the_beast" class="mw-redirect" title="Mark of the beast">mark of the beast</a> in the number 666, and that he came up with the price because he liked "repeating digits".<sup id="cite_ref-VintageNews_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VintageNews-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple Computer, Inc. was incorporated on January 3, 1977,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200410_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200410-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Apple_FAQ_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple_FAQ-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> without Wayne, who had left and sold his share of the company back to Jobs and Wozniak for $800 only twelve days after having co-founded it.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> Multimillionaire <a href="/wiki/Mike_Markkula" title="Mike Markkula">Mike Markkula</a> provided essential business expertise and funding of <span style="white-space: nowrap">$250,000</span>&#32;(equivalent to $1,257,000 in 2023) to Jobs and Wozniak during the incorporation of Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> During the first five years of operations, revenues grew exponentially, doubling about every four months. Between September 1977 and September 1980, yearly sales grew from $775,000 to <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$118</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million, an average annual growth rate of 533%.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Apple_II" title="Apple II">Apple II</a>, also designed by Wozniak, was introduced on April 16, 1977, at the first <a href="/wiki/West_Coast_Computer_Faire" title="West Coast Computer Faire">West Coast Computer Faire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200412_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200412-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> It differs from its major rivals, the <a href="/wiki/TRS-80" title="TRS-80">TRS-80</a> and <a href="/wiki/Commodore_PET" title="Commodore PET">Commodore PET</a>, because of its character cell-based color graphics and <a href="/wiki/Open_architecture" title="Open architecture">open architecture</a>. The Apple I and early Apple II models use ordinary <a href="/wiki/Cassette_tape" title="Cassette tape">audio cassette tapes</a> as storage devices, which were superseded by the <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1154941027">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);clip-path:polygon(0px 0px,0px 0px,0px 0px);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span class="frac">5<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>&#8260;<span class="den">4</span></span>-inch <a href="/wiki/Floppy_disk" title="Floppy disk">floppy disk</a> drive and interface called the <a href="/wiki/Disk_II" title="Disk II">Disk II</a> in 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Apple II was chosen to be the desktop platform for the first "<a href="/wiki/Killer_application" title="Killer application">killer application</a>" of the business world: <a href="/wiki/VisiCalc" title="VisiCalc">VisiCalc</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Spreadsheet" title="Spreadsheet">spreadsheet</a> <a href="/wiki/Computer_program" title="Computer program">program</a> released in 1979.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> VisiCalc created a business market for the Apple II and gave home users an additional reason to buy an Apple II: compatibility with the office,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15_29-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> but Apple II market share remained behind <a href="/wiki/Home_computer" title="Home computer">home computers</a> made by competitors such as <a href="/wiki/Atari,_Inc." title="Atari, Inc.">Atari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Commodore_International" title="Commodore International">Commodore</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tandy_Computers" class="mw-redirect" title="Tandy Computers">Tandy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On December 12, 1980, Apple (ticker symbol "AAPL") went public selling 4.6&#160;million shares at $22 per share ($.10 per share when adjusting for <a href="/wiki/Stock_split" title="Stock split">stock splits</a> as of September&#160;3,&#32;2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>),<sup id="cite_ref-Apple_FAQ_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple_FAQ-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> generating over $100&#160;million, which was more capital than any IPO since <a href="/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company" title="Ford Motor Company">Ford Motor Company</a> in 1956.<sup id="cite_ref-EDNAAPLSTOCK_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EDNAAPLSTOCK-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> By the end of the day, 300&#160;millionaires were created, including Jobs and Wozniak, from a stock price of $29 per share<sup id="cite_ref-DEDIPO_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DEDIPO-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> and a market cap of $1.778&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-EDNAAPLSTOCK_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EDNAAPLSTOCK-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DEDIPO_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DEDIPO-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1980.E2.80.931990:_Success_with_Macintosh"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1980–1990:_Success_with_Macintosh">1980–1990: Success with Macintosh</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mac_models" title="List of Mac models">List of Mac models</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Apple_II_family" class="mw-redirect" title="Timeline of the Apple II family">Timeline of the Apple II family</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Macintosh,_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png/220px-Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="156" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png/330px-Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png/440px-Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png 2x" data-file-width="865" data-file-height="615" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_128k" class="mw-redirect" title="Macintosh 128k">Macintosh</a>, released in 1984, is the first mass-market personal computer to feature an integral graphical user interface and mouse.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In December 1979, Steve Jobs and Apple employees, including Jef Raskin, visited Xerox PARC, where they observed the Xerox Alto, featuring a graphical user interface (GUI). Apple subsequently negotiated access to PARC's technology, leading to Apple's option to buy shares at a preferential rate. This visit influenced Jobs to implement a GUI in Apple's products, starting with the Apple Lisa. Despite being pioneering as a mass-marketed GUI computer, the Lisa suffered from high costs and limited software options, leading to commercial failure.
</p><p>Jobs, angered by being pushed off the Lisa team, took over the company's <a href="/wiki/Macintosh" class="mw-redirect" title="Macintosh">Macintosh</a> division. Wozniak and Raskin had envisioned the Macintosh as a low-cost computer with a text-based interface like the Apple II, but a plane crash in 1981 forced Wozniak to step back from the project. Jobs quickly redefined the Macintosh as a graphical system that would be cheaper than the Lisa, undercutting his former division.<sup id="cite_ref-TheVerge_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TheVerge-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup> Jobs was also hostile to the Apple II division, which at the time, generated most of the company's revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-rice19850415_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rice19850415-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1984, Apple launched the Macintosh, the first personal computer without a bundled <a href="/wiki/Programming_language" title="Programming language">programming language</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IsProgramingObsolete_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IsProgramingObsolete-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> Its debut was signified by "<a href="/wiki/1984_(advertisement)" title="1984 (advertisement)">1984</a>", a <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$1.5</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million television advertisement directed by <a href="/wiki/Ridley_Scott" title="Ridley Scott">Ridley Scott</a> that aired during the third quarter of <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XVIII" title="Super Bowl XVIII">Super Bowl XVIII</a> on January 22, 1984.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> This was hailed as a watershed event for Apple's success<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> and was called a "masterpiece" by <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> and one of the greatest TV advertisements of all time by <i><a href="/wiki/TV_Guide" title="TV Guide">TV Guide</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The advertisement created great interest in <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_128K" title="Macintosh 128K">Macintosh</a>, and sales were initially good, but began to taper off dramatically after the first three months as reviews started to come in. Jobs had required <span class="nowrap">128 kilobytes</span> of RAM, which limited its speed and software in favor of aspiring for a projected price point of <span style="white-space: nowrap">$1,000</span>&#32;(equivalent to $2,900 in 2023). The Macintosh shipped for <span style="white-space: nowrap">$2,495</span>&#32;(equivalent to $7,300 in 2023), a price panned by critics due to its slow performance.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 195">&#58;&#8202;195&#8202;</span></sup> In early 1985, this sales slump triggered a power struggle between Steve Jobs and CEO <a href="/wiki/John_Sculley" title="John Sculley">John Sculley</a>, who had been hired away from <a href="/wiki/PepsiCo" title="PepsiCo">Pepsi</a> two years earlier by Jobs<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> saying, "Do you want to sell sugar water for the rest of your life or come with me and change the world?"<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> Sculley removed Jobs as the head of the Macintosh division, with unanimous support from the Apple board of directors.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The board of directors instructed Sculley to contain Jobs and his ability to launch expensive forays into untested products. Rather than submit to Sculley's direction, Jobs attempted to oust him from leadership.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156–157_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156–157-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jean-Louis_Gass%C3%A9e" title="Jean-Louis Gassée">Jean-Louis Gassée</a> informed Sculley that Jobs had been attempting to organize a <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat#Other" title="Coup d&#39;état">boardroom coup</a> and called an emergency meeting at which Apple's executive staff sided with Sculley and stripped Jobs of all operational duties.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156–157_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156–157-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> Jobs resigned from Apple in September 1985 and took several Apple employees with him to found <a href="/wiki/NeXT" title="NeXT">NeXT</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> Wozniak had also quit his active employment at Apple earlier in 1985 to pursue other ventures, expressing his frustration with Apple's treatment of the Apple II division and stating that the company had "been going in the wrong direction for the last five years".<sup id="cite_ref-rice19850415_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rice19850415-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wozemployee_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wozemployee-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> Wozniak remained employed by Apple as a representative,<sup id="cite_ref-wozemployee_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wozemployee-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> receiving a stipend estimated to be $120,000 per year.<sup id="cite_ref-iWoz_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iWoz-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> Jobs and Wozniak remained Apple shareholders following their departures.<sup id="cite_ref-wozstock_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wozstock-50">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After the departures of Jobs and Wozniak in 1985, Sculley launched the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_512K" title="Macintosh 512K">Macintosh 512K</a> that year with quadruple the RAM, and introduced the <a href="/wiki/LaserWriter" title="LaserWriter">LaserWriter</a>, the first reasonably priced <a href="/wiki/PostScript" title="PostScript">PostScript</a> <a href="/wiki/Laser_printer" class="mw-redirect" title="Laser printer">laser printer</a>. <a href="/wiki/Adobe_PageMaker" title="Adobe PageMaker">PageMaker</a>, an early <a href="/wiki/Desktop_publishing" title="Desktop publishing">desktop publishing</a> application taking advantage of the PostScript language, was also released by <a href="/wiki/Aldus_Corporation" title="Aldus Corporation">Aldus Corporation</a> in July 1985.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004158–159_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004158–159-51">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> It has been suggested that the combination of Macintosh, LaserWriter, and PageMaker was responsible for the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Desktop_publishing" title="Desktop publishing">desktop publishing</a> market.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>This dominant position in the desktop publishing market<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> allowed the company to focus on higher price points, the so-called "high-right policy" named for the position on a chart of price vs. profits. Newer models selling at higher price points offered higher <a href="/wiki/Profit_margin" title="Profit margin">profit margin</a>, and appeared to have no effect on total sales as <a href="/wiki/Power_user" title="Power user">power users</a> snapped up every increase in speed. Although some worried about pricing themselves out of the market, the high-right policy was in full force by the mid-1980s, due to Jean-Louis Gassée's slogan of "fifty-five or die", referring to the 55% <a href="/wiki/Profit_margin" title="Profit margin">profit margins</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_II" title="Macintosh II">Macintosh II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-insidestoryCarlton_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-insidestoryCarlton-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 79–80">&#58;&#8202;79–80&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>This policy began to backfire late in the decade as desktop publishing programs appeared on <a href="/wiki/IBM_PC_compatible" title="IBM PC compatible">IBM PC compatibles</a> with some of the same functionality of the Macintosh at far lower price points. The company lost its dominant position in the desktop publishing market and estranged many of its original consumer customer base who could no longer afford Apple products. The <a href="/wiki/Economics_of_Christmas" title="Economics of Christmas">Christmas season</a> of 1989 was the first in the company's history to have declining sales, which led to a 20% drop in Apple's stock price.<sup id="cite_ref-insidestoryCarlton_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-insidestoryCarlton-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 117–129">&#58;&#8202;117–129&#8202;</span></sup> During this period, the relationship between Sculley and Gassée deteriorated, leading Sculley to effectively demote Gassée in January 1990 by appointing <a href="/wiki/Michael_Spindler" title="Michael Spindler">Michael Spindler</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Chief_operating_officer" title="Chief operating officer">chief operating officer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004184–185_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004184–185-55">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> Gassée left the company later that year.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004160_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004160-56">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1990.E2.80.931997:_Decline_and_restructuring"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1990–1997:_Decline_and_restructuring">1990–1997: Decline and restructuring</span></h3>
<p>The company pivoted strategy and in October 1990 introduced three lower-cost models, the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Classic" title="Macintosh Classic">Macintosh Classic</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_LC" title="Macintosh LC">Macintosh LC</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_IIsi" title="Macintosh IIsi">Macintosh IIsi</a>, all of which saw significant sales due to pent-up demand.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004128_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004128-57">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> In 1991, Apple introduced the hugely successful <a href="/wiki/PowerBook_100_series" title="PowerBook 100 series">PowerBook</a> with a design that set the current shape for almost all modern laptops. The same year, Apple introduced <a href="/wiki/System_7" title="System 7">System 7</a>, a major upgrade to the Macintosh operating system, adding color to the interface and introducing new networking capabilities.
</p><p>
The success of the lower-cost Macs and PowerBook brought increasing revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-lemsculley_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lemsculley-58">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> For some time, Apple was doing very well, introducing fresh new products at increasing profits. The magazine <i><a href="/wiki/MacAddict" class="mw-redirect" title="MacAddict">MacAddict</a></i> named the period between 1989 and 1991 as the "first golden age" of the Macintosh.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup></p><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_PenLite_prototype,_1992.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Apple_PenLite_prototype%2C_1992.jpg/220px-Apple_PenLite_prototype%2C_1992.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Apple_PenLite_prototype%2C_1992.jpg/330px-Apple_PenLite_prototype%2C_1992.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Apple_PenLite_prototype%2C_1992.jpg/440px-Apple_PenLite_prototype%2C_1992.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3823" data-file-height="2321" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/PenLite" class="mw-redirect" title="PenLite">PenLite</a> is Apple's first tablet computer prototype, created in 1992 to bring the Mac OS to a tablet. It was canceled in favor of the <a href="/wiki/Newton_(platform)" class="mw-redirect" title="Newton (platform)">Newton</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>The success of lower-cost consumer Macs, especially the LC, cannibalized higher-priced machines. To address this, management introduced several new brands, selling largely identical machines at different price points, for different markets: the high-end <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Quadra" title="Macintosh Quadra">Quadra</a> series, the mid-range <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Centris" title="Macintosh Centris">Centris</a> series, and the consumer-marketed <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Performa" title="Macintosh Performa">Performa</a> series. This led to significant consumer confusion between so many models.<sup id="cite_ref-vawperforma_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vawperforma-61">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early 1990s, the <a href="/wiki/Apple_II_series" title="Apple II series">Apple II series</a> was discontinued. It was expensive to produce, and the company decided it was still absorbing sales from lower-cost Macintosh models. After the launch of the LC, Apple encouraged developers to create applications for Macintosh rather than Apple II, and authorized salespersons to redirect consumers from Apple II and toward Macintosh.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Apple_IIe" title="Apple IIe">Apple IIe</a> was discontinued in 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple experimented with several other unsuccessful consumer targeted products during the 1990s, including <a href="/wiki/Apple_QuickTake" title="Apple QuickTake">QuickTake</a> <a href="/wiki/Digital_camera" title="Digital camera">digital cameras</a>, <a href="/wiki/PowerCD" title="PowerCD">PowerCD</a> portable CD audio players, <a href="/wiki/AppleDesign_Powered_Speakers" class="mw-redirect" title="AppleDesign Powered Speakers">speakers</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Bandai_Pippin" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Bandai Pippin">Pippin video game console</a>, the <a href="/wiki/EWorld" title="EWorld">eWorld</a> online service, and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Interactive_Television_Box" title="Apple Interactive Television Box">Apple Interactive Television Box</a>. Enormous resources were invested in the problematic <a href="/wiki/Newton_(platform)" class="mw-redirect" title="Newton (platform)">Newton</a> tablet division, based on John Sculley's unrealistic market forecasts.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout this period, Microsoft continued to gain market share with <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows" title="Microsoft Windows">Windows</a> by focusing on delivering software to inexpensive personal computers, while Apple was delivering a richly engineered but expensive experience.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> Apple relied on high profit margins and never developed a clear response; it sued Microsoft for making a GUI similar to the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Lisa" title="Apple Lisa">Lisa</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Apple_Computer,_Inc._v._Microsoft_Corp." title="Apple Computer, Inc. v. Microsoft Corp.">Apple Computer, Inc. v. Microsoft Corp.</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-lemms_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lemms-66">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> The lawsuit dragged on for years and was finally dismissed.
</p><p>The major product flops and the rapid loss of market share to Windows sullied Apple's reputation, and in 1993 Sculley was replaced as CEO by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Spindler" title="Michael Spindler">Michael Spindler</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Under Spindler, Apple, <a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">IBM</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Motorola" title="Motorola">Motorola</a> formed the <a href="/wiki/AIM_alliance" title="AIM alliance">AIM alliance</a> in 1994 to create a new computing platform (the <a href="/wiki/PowerPC_Reference_Platform" title="PowerPC Reference Platform">PowerPC Reference Platform</a> or PReP), with IBM and Motorola hardware coupled with Apple software. The AIM alliance hoped that PReP's performance and Apple's software would leave the PC far behind and thus counter the dominance of Windows. That year, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh" title="Power Macintosh">Power Macintosh</a>, the first of many computers with Motorola's <a href="/wiki/PowerPC" title="PowerPC">PowerPC</a> processor.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the wake of the alliance, Apple opened up to the idea of allowing Motorola and other companies to build <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_clone" title="Macintosh clone">Macintosh clones</a>. Over the next two years, 75 distinct Macintosh clone models were introduced. However, by 1996, Apple executives were worried that the clones were cannibalizing sales of its own high-end computers, where profit margins were highest.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmXnw5tM8QRwCpgPA254_254–256&#93;_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidmXnw5tM8QRwCpgPA254_254–256]-69">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1996, Spindler was replaced by <a href="/wiki/Gil_Amelio" title="Gil Amelio">Gil Amelio</a> as CEO, who was hired for his reputation as a corporate rehabilitator. Amelio made deep changes, including extensive layoffs and cost-cutting.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>This period was also marked by numerous failed attempts to modernize the Macintosh operating system (MacOS). The original Macintosh operating system (<a href="/wiki/System_1" title="System 1">System 1</a>) was not built for multitasking (running several applications at once). The company attempted to correct this by introducing <a href="/wiki/Cooperative_multitasking" title="Cooperative multitasking">cooperative multitasking</a> in System 5, but still decided it needed a more modern approach.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> This led to the <a href="/wiki/Taligent" title="Taligent">Pink</a> project in 1988, <a href="/wiki/A/UX" title="A/UX">A/UX</a> that year, <a href="/wiki/Copland_(operating_system)" title="Copland (operating system)">Copland</a> in 1994, and evaluated the purchase of <a href="/wiki/BeOS" title="BeOS">BeOS</a> in 1996. Talks with Be stalled when the CEO, former Apple executive <a href="/wiki/Jean-Louis_Gass%C3%A9e" title="Jean-Louis Gassée">Jean-Louis Gassée</a>, demanded $300 million instead of Apple's $125 million offer.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Only weeks away from <a href="/wiki/Bankruptcy" title="Bankruptcy">bankruptcy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> Apple's board preferred <a href="/wiki/NeXTSTEP" title="NeXTSTEP">NeXTSTEP</a> and purchased <a href="/wiki/NeXT" title="NeXT">NeXT</a> in late 1996 for $400 million, and retained <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1997.E2.80.932007:_Return_to_profitability"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1997–2007:_Return_to_profitability">1997–2007: Return to profitability</span></h3>
<p>The NeXT acquisition was finalized on February 9, 1997,<sup id="cite_ref-archive_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-archive-75">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup> and the board brought Jobs back to Apple as an advisor. On July 9, 1997, Jobs staged a boardroom coup that resulted in Amelio's resignation after overseeing a three-year record-low stock price and crippling financial losses.
</p><p>The board named Jobs as interim CEO and he immediately reviewed the product lineup. Jobs canceled 70% of models, ending 3,000 jobs and paring to the core of its computer offerings.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> The next month, in August 1997, Steve Jobs convinced Microsoft to make a $150&#160;million investment in Apple and a commitment to continue developing Mac software.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> This was seen as an "antitrust insurance policy" for Microsoft which had recently settled with the Department of Justice over anti-competitive practices in the <i><a href="/wiki/United_States_v._Microsoft_Corp." title="United States v. Microsoft Corp.">United States v. Microsoft Corp.</a></i> case.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup> Around then, Jobs donated Apple's internal library and archives to <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a>, to focus more on the present and the future rather than the past.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> He ended the Mac clone deals and in September 1997, purchased the largest clone maker, <a href="/wiki/Power_Computing_Corporation" title="Power Computing Corporation">Power Computing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup> On November 10, 1997, the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store_(online)" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Store (online)">Apple Store</a> website launched, which was tied to a new build-to-order manufacturing model similar to PC manufacturer <a href="/wiki/Dell" title="Dell">Dell</a>'s success.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The moves paid off for Jobs; at the end of his first year as CEO, the company had a $309 million profit.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:242px;max-width:242px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:131px;max-width:131px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:120px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:IMac_G3_Bondi_Blue,_three-quarters_view.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/IMac_G3_Bondi_Blue%2C_three-quarters_view.png/129px-IMac_G3_Bondi_Blue%2C_three-quarters_view.png" decoding="async" width="129" height="120" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/IMac_G3_Bondi_Blue%2C_three-quarters_view.png/194px-IMac_G3_Bondi_Blue%2C_three-quarters_view.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/IMac_G3_Bondi_Blue%2C_three-quarters_view.png/258px-IMac_G3_Bondi_Blue%2C_three-quarters_view.png 2x" data-file-width="3869" data-file-height="3608" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">iMac</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:107px;max-width:107px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:120px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Clamshell_iBook_G3.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Clamshell_iBook_G3.jpg/105px-Clamshell_iBook_G3.jpg" decoding="async" width="105" height="121" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Clamshell_iBook_G3.jpg/158px-Clamshell_iBook_G3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Clamshell_iBook_G3.jpg/210px-Clamshell_iBook_G3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="398" data-file-height="458" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">iBook</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:132px;max-width:132px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:103px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Yosemite.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Apple_Yosemite.JPG/130px-Apple_Yosemite.JPG" decoding="async" width="130" height="104" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Apple_Yosemite.JPG/195px-Apple_Yosemite.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Apple_Yosemite.JPG/260px-Apple_Yosemite.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2144" data-file-height="1715" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">Power Macintosh G3</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:106px;max-width:106px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:103px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_PowerBook_G3_500_Pismo-2763.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Apple_PowerBook_G3_500_Pismo-2763.jpg/104px-Apple_PowerBook_G3_500_Pismo-2763.jpg" decoding="async" width="104" height="104" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Apple_PowerBook_G3_500_Pismo-2763.jpg/156px-Apple_PowerBook_G3_500_Pismo-2763.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Apple_PowerBook_G3_500_Pismo-2763.jpg/208px-Apple_PowerBook_G3_500_Pismo-2763.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3159" data-file-height="3159" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">PowerBook G3</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>On May 6, 1998, Apple introduced a new all-in-one computer reminiscent of the original Macintosh: the <a href="/wiki/IMac_G3" title="IMac G3">iMac</a>. The iMac was a huge success with 800,000 units sold in its first five months<sup id="cite_ref-800kimacs_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-800kimacs-83">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> and ushered in major shifts in the industry by abandoning legacy technologies like the <a href="/wiki/Floppy_disk" title="Floppy disk"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1154941027"><span class="frac">3<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>&#8260;<span class="den">2</span></span>-inch diskette</a>, being an early adopter of the <a href="/wiki/USB" title="USB">USB</a> connector, and coming pre-installed with Internet connectivity (the "i" in iMac)<sup id="cite_ref-Alyson_Raletz_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alyson_Raletz-84">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> via Ethernet and a dial-up modem. Its striking teardrop shape and translucent materials were designed by <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Ive" class="mw-redirect" title="Jonathan Ive">Jonathan Ive</a>, who had been hired by Amelio, and who collaborated with Jobs for more than a decade to reshape Apple's product design.<sup id="cite_ref-Time_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-85">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A little more than a year later on July 21, 1999, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IBook" title="IBook">iBook</a> consumer laptop. It culminated Jobs's strategy to produce only four products: refined versions of the <a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh_G3" title="Power Macintosh G3">Power Macintosh G3</a> desktop and <a href="/wiki/PowerBook_G3" title="PowerBook G3">PowerBook G3</a> laptop for professionals, and the iMac desktop and iBook laptop for consumers. Jobs said the small product line allowed for a greater focus on quality and innovation.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Around then, Apple also completed numerous acquisitions to create a portfolio of digital media production software for both professionals and consumers. Apple acquired <a href="/wiki/Macromedia" title="Macromedia">Macromedia</a>'s Key Grip digital video editing software project which was launched as <a href="/wiki/Final_Cut_Pro" title="Final Cut Pro">Final Cut Pro</a> in April 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> Key Grip's development also led to Apple's release of the consumer video-editing product <a href="/wiki/IMovie" title="IMovie">iMovie</a> in October 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-Bell_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bell-89">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> Apple acquired the German company Astarte in April 2000, which had developed the <a href="/wiki/DVD_authoring" title="DVD authoring">DVD authoring</a> software DVDirector, which Apple repackaged as the professional-oriented <a href="/wiki/DVD_Studio_Pro" title="DVD Studio Pro">DVD Studio Pro</a>, and reused its technology to create <a href="/wiki/IDVD" title="IDVD">iDVD</a> for the consumer market.<sup id="cite_ref-Bell_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bell-89">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> In 2000, Apple purchased the <a href="/wiki/SoundJam_MP" title="SoundJam MP">SoundJam MP</a> audio player software from <a href="/wiki/Casady_%26_Greene" title="Casady &amp; Greene">Casady &amp; Greene</a>. Apple renamed the program <a href="/wiki/ITunes" title="ITunes">iTunes</a>, and simplified the user interface and added CD burning.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2001, Apple changed course with three announcements.
</p><p>First, on March 24, 2001, Apple announced the release of a new modern operating system, <a href="/wiki/Mac_OS_X" class="mw-redirect" title="Mac OS X">Mac OS X</a>. This was after numerous failed attempts in the early 1990s, and several years of development. Mac OS X is based on <a href="/wiki/NeXTSTEP" title="NeXTSTEP">NeXTSTEP</a>, <a href="/wiki/OpenStep" title="OpenStep">OPENSTEP</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Berkeley_Software_Distribution" title="Berkeley Software Distribution">BSD Unix</a>, to combine the stability, reliability, and security of <a href="/wiki/Unix" title="Unix">Unix</a> with the ease of use of an overhauled user interface. To aid migration from <a href="/wiki/Mac_OS_9" title="Mac OS 9">Mac OS 9</a>, the new operating system ran legacy applications within Mac OS X via the <a href="/wiki/Classic_Environment" class="mw-redirect" title="Classic Environment">Classic Environment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2001, the first two <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store" title="Apple Store">Apple Store</a> retail locations opened in Virginia and California,<sup id="cite_ref-First_stores_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-First_stores-92">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> offering an improved presentation of the company's products.<sup id="cite_ref-MacRumors_stores_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacRumors_stores-94">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> At the time, many speculated that the stores would fail,<sup id="cite_ref-fortune-best-retailer_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fortune-best-retailer-95">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup> but they became highly successful, and the first of more than 500 stores around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-96">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On October 23, 2001, the <a href="/wiki/IPod" title="IPod">iPod</a> portable digital audio player debuted. The product was first sold on November 10, 2001, and was phenomenally successful with over 100&#160;million units sold within six years.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2003, the <a href="/wiki/ITunes_Store" title="ITunes Store">iTunes Store</a> was introduced with <a href="/wiki/Music_download" title="Music download">music downloads</a> for 99¢ a song and iPod integration. It quickly became the market leader in online music services, with over five billion downloads by June 19, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup> Two years later, the iTunes Store was the world's largest music retailer.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2002, Apple purchased <a href="/wiki/Nothing_Real" title="Nothing Real">Nothing Real</a> for its advanced digital <a href="/wiki/Compositing" title="Compositing">compositing</a> application <a href="/wiki/Shake_(software)" title="Shake (software)">Shake</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Emagic" title="Emagic">Emagic</a> for the music productivity application <a href="/wiki/Logic_Pro" title="Logic Pro">Logic</a>. The purchase of Emagic made Apple the first computer manufacturer to own a music software company. The acquisition was followed by the development of Apple's consumer-level <a href="/wiki/GarageBand" title="GarageBand">GarageBand</a> application.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> The release of <a href="/wiki/IPhoto" title="IPhoto">iPhoto</a> that year completed the <a href="/wiki/ILife" title="ILife">iLife</a> suite.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:MacBook_Pro.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/MacBook_Pro.jpg/220px-MacBook_Pro.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="177" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/MacBook_Pro.jpg/330px-MacBook_Pro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/MacBook_Pro.jpg/440px-MacBook_Pro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1623" data-file-height="1305" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/MacBook_Pro" title="MacBook Pro">MacBook Pro</a> is Apple's first laptop with an <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a> microprocessor, introduced in 2006.</figcaption></figure>
<p>At the <a href="/wiki/Worldwide_Developers_Conference" title="Worldwide Developers Conference">Worldwide Developers Conference</a> keynote address on June 6, 2005, Jobs announced that Apple would move away from PowerPC processors, and the <a href="/wiki/Mac_transition_to_Intel_processors" title="Mac transition to Intel processors">Mac would transition to Intel processors</a> in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-printel_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-printel-103">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup> On January 10, 2006, the new <a href="/wiki/MacBook_Pro" title="MacBook Pro">MacBook Pro</a> and <a href="/wiki/IMac" title="IMac">iMac</a> became the first Apple computers to use Intel's <a href="/wiki/Core_Duo" class="mw-redirect" title="Core Duo">Core Duo</a> CPU. By August 7, 2006, Apple made the transition to Intel chips for the entire Mac product line—over one year sooner than announced.<sup id="cite_ref-printel_103-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-printel-103">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup> The Power Mac, iBook, and PowerBook brands were retired during the transition; the <a href="/wiki/Mac_Pro" title="Mac Pro">Mac Pro</a>, <a href="/wiki/MacBook" title="MacBook">MacBook</a>, and MacBook Pro became their respective successors.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup> Apple also introduced <a href="/wiki/Boot_Camp_(software)" title="Boot Camp (software)">Boot Camp</a> in 2006 to help users install <a href="/wiki/Windows_XP" title="Windows XP">Windows XP</a> or <a href="/wiki/Windows_Vista" title="Windows Vista">Windows Vista</a> on their Intel Macs alongside Mac OS X.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple's success during this period was evident in its <a href="/wiki/Stock_price" class="mw-redirect" title="Stock price">stock price</a>. Between early 2003 and 2006, the price of Apple's stock increased more than tenfold, from around $6 per share (<a href="/wiki/Split-adjusted" class="mw-redirect" title="Split-adjusted">split-adjusted</a>) to over $80.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> When Apple surpassed <a href="/wiki/Dell" title="Dell">Dell</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Market_cap" class="mw-redirect" title="Market cap">market cap</a> in January 2006,<sup id="cite_ref-modell_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-modell-107">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> Jobs sent an email to Apple employees saying Dell's CEO <a href="/wiki/Michael_Dell" title="Michael Dell">Michael Dell</a> should eat his words.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup> Nine years prior, Dell had said that if he ran Apple he would "shut it down and give the money back to the shareholders".<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="2007.E2.80.932011:_Success_with_mobile_devices"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2007–2011:_Success_with_mobile_devices">2007–2011: Success with mobile devices</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg/220px-First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg/330px-First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg/440px-First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2016" data-file-height="1512" /></a><figcaption>The newly announced iPhone was on display at the 2007 <a href="/wiki/MacWorld_Expo" class="mw-redirect" title="MacWorld Expo">MacWorld Expo</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>During his keynote speech at the Macworld Expo on January 9, 2007, Jobs announced the renaming of Apple Computer, Inc. to Apple Inc., because the company had shifted its emphasis from computers to consumer electronics.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> This event also saw the announcement of the <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV" title="Apple TV">Apple TV</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup> The company sold 270,000 iPhone units during the first 30 hours of sales,<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> and the device was called "a game changer for the industry".<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In an article posted on Apple's website on February 6, 2007, Jobs wrote that Apple would be willing to sell music on the <a href="/wiki/ITunes_Store" title="ITunes Store">iTunes Store</a> without <a href="/wiki/Digital_rights_management" title="Digital rights management">digital rights management</a>, thereby allowing tracks to be played on third-party players if record labels would agree to drop the technology.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> On April 2, 2007, Apple and <a href="/wiki/EMI" title="EMI">EMI</a> jointly announced the removal of DRM technology from EMI's catalog in the iTunes Store, effective in May 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> Other record labels eventually followed suit and Apple published a press release in January 2009 to announce that all songs on the iTunes Store are available without their <a href="/wiki/FairPlay" title="FairPlay">FairPlay</a> DRM.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2008, Apple launched the <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" class="mw-redirect" title="App Store (iOS)">App Store</a> to sell third-party applications for the <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a> and <a href="/wiki/IPod_Touch" title="IPod Touch">iPod Touch</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> Within a month, the store sold 60&#160;million applications and registered an average daily revenue of $1&#160;million, with Jobs speculating in August 2008 that the <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS/iPadOS)" class="mw-redirect" title="App Store (iOS/iPadOS)">App Store</a> could become a billion-dollar business for Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup> By October 2008, Apple was the third-largest mobile handset supplier in the world due to the popularity of the iPhone.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 14, 2009, Jobs announced in an internal memo that he would be taking a six-month medical <a href="/wiki/Leave_of_absence" title="Leave of absence">leave of absence</a> from Apple until the end of June 2009 and would spend the time focusing on his health. In the email, Jobs stated that "the curiosity over my personal health continues to be a distraction not only for me and my family, but everyone else at Apple as well", and explained that the break would allow the company "to focus on delivering extraordinary products".<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup> Though Jobs was absent, Apple recorded its best non-holiday quarter (Q1 FY 2009) during the <a href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" class="mw-redirect" title="Late-2000s recession">recession</a> with revenue of $8.16&#160;billion and profit of $1.21&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After years of speculation and multiple rumored "leaks", Apple unveiled a large screen, tablet-like media device known as the <a href="/wiki/IPad" title="IPad">iPad</a> on January 27, 2010. The iPad ran the same touch-based operating system as the iPhone, and all iPhone apps were compatible with the iPad. This gave the iPad a large app catalog on launch, though having very little development time before the release. Later that year on April 3, 2010, the iPad was launched in the U.S. It sold more than 300,000 units on its first day, and 500,000 by the end of the first week.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup> In May 2010, Apple's market cap exceeded that of competitor <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a> for the first time since 1989.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2010, Apple released the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_4" title="IPhone 4">iPhone 4</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> which introduced <a href="/wiki/Video_calling" class="mw-redirect" title="Video calling">video calling</a> using <a href="/wiki/FaceTime" title="FaceTime">FaceTime</a>, <a href="/wiki/Computer_multitasking" title="Computer multitasking">multitasking</a>, and a new design with an exposed <a href="/wiki/Stainless_steel" title="Stainless steel">stainless steel</a> frame as the phone's antenna system. Later that year, Apple again refreshed the <a href="/wiki/IPod" title="IPod">iPod</a> line by introducing a <a href="/wiki/Multi-touch" title="Multi-touch">multi-touch</a> <a href="/wiki/IPod_Nano" title="IPod Nano">iPod Nano</a>, an iPod Touch with <a href="/wiki/FaceTime" title="FaceTime">FaceTime</a>, and an <a href="/wiki/IPod_Shuffle" title="IPod Shuffle">iPod Shuffle</a> that brought back the <a href="/wiki/Clickwheel" title="Clickwheel">clickwheel</a> buttons of earlier generations.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> It also introduced the smaller, cheaper second generation Apple TV which allowed renting of movies and shows.<sup id="cite_ref-yahoo1_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yahoo1-127">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 17, 2011, Jobs announced in an internal Apple memo that he would take another medical leave of absence for an indefinite period to allow him to focus on his health. Chief operating officer <a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a> assumed Jobs's day-to-day operations at Apple, although Jobs would still remain "involved in major strategic decisions".<sup id="cite_ref-JobsLeave2011_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JobsLeave2011-128">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup> Apple became the most valuable consumer-facing brand in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup> In June 2011, Jobs surprisingly took the stage and unveiled <a href="/wiki/ICloud" title="ICloud">iCloud</a>, an online storage and syncing service for music, photos, files, and software which replaced <a href="/wiki/MobileMe" title="MobileMe">MobileMe</a>, Apple's previous attempt at content syncing.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> This would be the last product launch Jobs would attend before his death.
</p><p>On August 24, 2011, Jobs resigned his position as CEO of Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup> He was replaced by Cook and Jobs became Apple's chairman. Apple did not have a chairman at the time<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup> and instead had two co-lead directors, <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Jung" title="Andrea Jung">Andrea Jung</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arthur_D._Levinson" title="Arthur D. Levinson">Arthur D. Levinson</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup> who continued with those titles until Levinson replaced Jobs as chairman of the board in November after Jobs's death.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="2011.E2.80.93present:_Post-Jobs_era.2C_Tim_Cook"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2011–present:_Post-Jobs_era,_Tim_Cook">2011–present: Post-Jobs era, Tim Cook</span></h3>
<p>On October 5, 2011, Steve Jobs died, marking the end of an era for Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> The next major product announcement by Apple was on January 19, 2012, when Apple's <a href="/wiki/Phil_Schiller" title="Phil Schiller">Phil Schiller</a> introduced <a href="/wiki/Apple_Books" title="Apple Books">iBook's</a> Textbooks for iOS and iBook Author for Mac OS X in New York City.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup> Jobs stated in the biography "Steve Jobs" that he wanted to reinvent the <a href="/wiki/Textbook" title="Textbook">textbook</a> industry and education.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>From 2011 to 2012, Apple released the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_4S" class="mw-redirect" title="IPhone 4S">iPhone 4S</a><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/IPhone_5" title="IPhone 5">iPhone 5</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup> which featured improved cameras, an <a href="/wiki/Intelligent_personal_assistant" class="mw-redirect" title="Intelligent personal assistant">intelligent software assistant</a> named <a href="/wiki/Siri" title="Siri">Siri</a>, and cloud-synced data with iCloud;
