the <a href="/wiki/IPad_(third_generation)" class="mw-redirect" title="IPad (third generation)">third</a>- and <a href="/wiki/IPad_(fourth_generation)" class="mw-redirect" title="IPad (fourth generation)">fourth</a>-generation iPads, which featured <a href="/wiki/Retina_Display" class="mw-redirect" title="Retina Display">Retina displays</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lightning_strikes_again_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lightning_strikes_again-141">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/IPad_Mini" title="IPad Mini">iPad Mini</a>, which featured a 7.9-inch screen in contrast to the iPad's 9.7-inch screen.<sup id="cite_ref-mini_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mini-142">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> These launches were successful, with the iPhone 5 (released September 21, 2012) becoming Apple's biggest iPhone launch with over two million pre-orders<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup> and sales of three million iPads in three days following the launch of the iPad Mini and fourth-generation iPad (released November 3, 2012).<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup> Apple also released a third-generation 13-inch <a href="/wiki/MacBook_Pro" title="MacBook Pro">MacBook Pro</a> with a Retina display and new <a href="/wiki/IMac" title="IMac">iMac</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mac_Mini" title="Mac Mini">Mac Mini</a> computers.<sup id="cite_ref-Lightning_strikes_again_141-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lightning_strikes_again-141">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mini_142-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mini-142">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 20, 2012, Apple's rising stock price increased the company's market capitalization to a then-record $624&#160;billion. This beat the non-inflation-adjusted record for market capitalization previously set by <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a> in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup> On August 24, 2012, a US jury ruled that Samsung should pay Apple $1.05&#160;billion (£665m) in damages in an <a href="/wiki/Intellectual_property" title="Intellectual property">intellectual property</a> lawsuit.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> Samsung appealed the damages award, which was reduced by $450&#160;million<sup id="cite_ref-FOSS_Patents_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOSS_Patents-148">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup> and further granted Samsung's request for a new trial.<sup id="cite_ref-FOSS_Patents_148-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOSS_Patents-148">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup> On November 10, 2012, Apple confirmed a global settlement that dismissed all existing lawsuits between Apple and HTC up to that date, in favor of a ten-year license agreement for current and future patents between the two companies.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> It is predicted that Apple will make <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$280</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million per year from this deal with HTC.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2014, Apple confirmed its intent to acquire <a href="/wiki/Dr._Dre" title="Dr. Dre">Dr. Dre</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Iovine" title="Jimmy Iovine">Jimmy Iovine</a>'s audio company <a href="/wiki/Beats_Electronics" title="Beats Electronics">Beats Electronics</a>—producer of the "Beats by Dr. Dre" line of headphones and speaker products, and operator of the music streaming service <a href="/wiki/Beats_Music" title="Beats Music">Beats Music</a>—for <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$3</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>billion, and to sell their products through Apple's retail outlets and resellers. Iovine believed that Beats had always "belonged" with Apple, as the company modeled itself after Apple's "unmatched ability to marry culture and technology." The acquisition was the largest purchase in Apple's history.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Watch_%E3%81%A7%E3%83%81%E3%82%A7%E3%83%83%E3%82%AF%E3%82%A4%E3%83%B3%E3%81%97%E3%81%BE%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F%EF%BC%81_2015_(17187691969).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Apple_Watch_%E3%81%A7%E3%83%81%E3%82%A7%E3%83%83%E3%82%AF%E3%82%A4%E3%83%B3%E3%81%97%E3%81%BE%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F%EF%BC%81_2015_%2817187691969%29.jpg/220px-Apple_Watch_%E3%81%A7%E3%83%81%E3%82%A7%E3%83%83%E3%82%AF%E3%82%A4%E3%83%B3%E3%81%97%E3%81%BE%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F%EF%BC%81_2015_%2817187691969%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Apple_Watch_%E3%81%A7%E3%83%81%E3%82%A7%E3%83%83%E3%82%AF%E3%82%A4%E3%83%B3%E3%81%97%E3%81%BE%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F%EF%BC%81_2015_%2817187691969%29.jpg/330px-Apple_Watch_%E3%81%A7%E3%83%81%E3%82%A7%E3%83%83%E3%82%AF%E3%82%A4%E3%83%B3%E3%81%97%E3%81%BE%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F%EF%BC%81_2015_%2817187691969%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Apple_Watch_%E3%81%A7%E3%83%81%E3%82%A7%E3%83%83%E3%82%AF%E3%82%A4%E3%83%B3%E3%81%97%E3%81%BE%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F%EF%BC%81_2015_%2817187691969%29.jpg/440px-Apple_Watch_%E3%81%A7%E3%83%81%E3%82%A7%E3%83%83%E3%82%AF%E3%82%A4%E3%83%B3%E3%81%97%E3%81%BE%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F%EF%BC%81_2015_%2817187691969%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="640" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch" title="Apple Watch">Apple Watch</a> first generation (2015)</figcaption></figure>
<p>During a press event on September 9, 2014, Apple introduced a <a href="/wiki/Smartwatch" title="Smartwatch">smartwatch</a> called the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch" title="Apple Watch">Apple Watch</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-verge-watchannounce_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-verge-watchannounce-152">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> Initially, Apple marketed the device as a <a href="/wiki/Fashion_accessory" title="Fashion accessory">fashion accessory</a><sup id="cite_ref-wp-fashion_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-fashion-153">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> and a complement to the iPhone, that would allow people to look at their smartphones less.<sup id="cite_ref-wired.com_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wired.com-154">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup> Over time, the company has focused on developing health and fitness-oriented features on the watch, in an effort to compete with dedicated <a href="/wiki/Activity_tracker" title="Activity tracker">activity trackers</a>.
</p><p>In January 2016, Apple announced that over one billion Apple devices were in active use worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On June 6, 2016, <i>Fortune</i> released Fortune 500, its list of companies ranked on revenue generation. In the trailing fiscal year of 2015, Apple was listed as the top tech company.<sup id="cite_ref-Top_Tech_Company_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Top_Tech_Company-156">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> It ranked third, overall, with <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$233</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>billion in revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-Top_Tech_Company_156-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Top_Tech_Company-156">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> This represents a movement upward of two spots from the previous year's list.<sup id="cite_ref-Top_Tech_Company_156-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Top_Tech_Company-156">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2017, Apple announced the <a href="/wiki/HomePod" title="HomePod">HomePod</a>, its <a href="/wiki/Smart_speaker" title="Smart speaker">smart speaker</a> aimed to compete against <a href="/wiki/Sonos" title="Sonos">Sonos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Home" class="mw-redirect" title="Google Home">Google Home</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Echo" title="Amazon Echo">Amazon Echo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup> Toward the end of the year, <i><a href="/wiki/TechCrunch" title="TechCrunch">TechCrunch</a></i> reported that Apple was acquiring <a href="/wiki/Shazam_(music_app)" title="Shazam (music app)">Shazam</a>, a company that introduced its products at WWDC and specializing in music, TV, film and advertising recognition.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> The acquisition was confirmed a few days later, reportedly costing Apple <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$400</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million, with media reports that the purchase looked like a move to acquire data and tools bolstering the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Music" title="Apple Music">Apple Music</a> streaming service.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> The purchase was approved by the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in September 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Also in June 2017, Apple appointed Jamie Erlicht and Zack Van Amburg to head the newly formed worldwide video unit. In November 2017, Apple announced it was branching out into original scripted programming: <a href="/wiki/Top_of_the_Morning_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Top of the Morning (TV series)">a drama series starring</a> <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Aniston" title="Jennifer Aniston">Jennifer Aniston</a> and <a href="/wiki/Reese_Witherspoon" title="Reese Witherspoon">Reese Witherspoon</a>, and a reboot of the anthology series <a href="/wiki/Amazing_Stories_(2020_TV_series)" title="Amazing Stories (2020 TV series)">Amazing Stories</a> with <a href="/wiki/Steven_Spielberg" title="Steven Spielberg">Steven Spielberg</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup> In June 2018, Apple signed the <a href="/wiki/Writers_Guild_of_America" title="Writers Guild of America">Writers Guild of America</a>'s minimum basic agreement and <a href="/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey" title="Oprah Winfrey">Oprah Winfrey</a> to a multi-year content partnership.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> Additional partnerships for original series include <a href="/wiki/Sesame_Workshop" title="Sesame Workshop">Sesame Workshop</a> and <a href="/wiki/DHX_Media" class="mw-redirect" title="DHX Media">DHX Media</a> and its subsidiary <a href="/wiki/Peanuts_Worldwide" class="mw-redirect" title="Peanuts Worldwide">Peanuts Worldwide</a>, and a partnership with <a href="/wiki/A24" title="A24">A24</a> to create original films.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Apple_Inc._media_events#Apple_Special_Event_(September_12,_2017)" title="List of Apple Inc. media events">Apple Special Event</a> in September 2017, the <a href="/wiki/AirPower_(Apple)" title="AirPower (Apple)">AirPower</a> wireless charger was announced alongside the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_X" title="IPhone X">iPhone X</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPhone_8" title="IPhone 8">iPhone 8</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch#Third_generation_(Series_3)" title="Apple Watch">Watch Series 3</a>. The AirPower was intended to wirelessly charge multiple devices, simultaneously. Though initially set to release in early 2018, the AirPower would be canceled in March 2019, marking the first cancellation of a device under Cook's leadership.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 19, 2020, Apple's share price briefly topped $467.77, making it the first US company with a market capitalization of <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$2</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>trillion.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Macbook_Air_M1_Silver_PNG.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Macbook_Air_M1_Silver_PNG.png/220px-Macbook_Air_M1_Silver_PNG.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Macbook_Air_M1_Silver_PNG.png/330px-Macbook_Air_M1_Silver_PNG.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Macbook_Air_M1_Silver_PNG.png/440px-Macbook_Air_M1_Silver_PNG.png 2x" data-file-width="2386" data-file-height="2386" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/MacBook_Air_(Apple_silicon)" title="MacBook Air (Apple silicon)">MacBook Air M1</a> (2020)</figcaption></figure>
<p>During its annual <a href="/wiki/WWDC" class="mw-redirect" title="WWDC">WWDC</a> keynote speech on June 22, 2020, Apple announced it would move away from Intel processors, and the <a href="/wiki/Mac_transition_to_Apple_silicon" title="Mac transition to Apple silicon">Mac would transition to processors developed in-house</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> The announcement was expected by industry analysts, and it has been noted that Macs featuring Apple's processors would allow for big increases in performance over current Intel-based models.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> On November 10, 2020, the MacBook Air, MacBook Pro, and the Mac Mini became the first Mac devices powered by an Apple-designed processor, the <a href="/wiki/Apple_M1" title="Apple M1">Apple M1</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2022, it was reported that <a href="/wiki/Samsung_Electro-Mechanics" title="Samsung Electro-Mechanics">Samsung Electro-Mechanics</a> would be collaborating with Apple on its M2 chip instead of <a href="/wiki/LG_Innotek" title="LG Innotek">LG Innotek</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> Developer logs showed that at least nine Mac models with four different M2 chips were being tested.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> reported that Apple's effort to develop its own chips left it better prepared to deal with the semiconductor shortage that emerged during the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, which led to increased profitability, with sales of M1-based Mac computers rising sharply in 2020 and 2021. It also inspired other companies like <a href="/wiki/Tesla,_Inc." title="Tesla, Inc.">Tesla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amazon_(company)" title="Amazon (company)">Amazon</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Meta_Platforms" title="Meta Platforms">Meta Platforms</a> to pursue a similar path.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2022, Apple opened an online store that allowed anyone in the US to view repair manuals and order replacement parts for specific recent iPhones, although the difference in cost between this method and official repair is anticipated to be minimal.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2022, a trademark was filed for RealityOS, an operating system reportedly intended for virtual and augmented reality headsets, first mentioned in 2017. According to Bloomberg, the headset may come out in 2023.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> Further insider reports state that the device uses iris scanning for payment confirmation and signing into accounts.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On June 18, 2022, the Apple Store in <a href="/wiki/Towson,_Maryland" title="Towson, Maryland">Towson, Maryland</a> became the first to unionize in the U.S., with the employees voting to join the <a href="/wiki/International_Association_of_Machinists_and_Aerospace_Workers" title="International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers">International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On July 7, 2022, Apple added Lockdown Mode to macOS 13 and iOS 16, as a response to the earlier Pegasus revelations; the mode increases security protections for high-risk users against targeted <a href="/wiki/Zero-day_(computing)" class="mw-redirect" title="Zero-day (computing)">zero-day</a> malware.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple launched a <a href="/wiki/Buy_now,_pay_later" title="Buy now, pay later">buy now, pay later</a> service called 'Apple Pay Later' for its <a href="/wiki/Apple_Wallet" title="Apple Wallet">Apple Wallet</a> users in March 2023. The program allows its users to apply for loans between $50 and $1,000 to make online or in-app purchases and then repaying them through four installments spread over six weeks without any interest or fees.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2023, Apple agreed to a $25 million settlement in a <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">U.S. Department of Justice</a> case that alleged Apple was discriminating against U.S. citizens in hiring. Apple created jobs that were not listed online and required paper submission to apply for, while advertising these jobs to foreign workers as part of recruitment for <a href="/wiki/Permanent_Labor_Certification#Program_electronic_review_management" title="Permanent Labor Certification">PERM</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2024, Apple announced compliance with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>'s competition law, with major changes to the App Store and other services, effective March 7. This enables iOS users in the 27-nation bloc to use alternative app stores, and alternative payment methods within apps. This adds a menu in Safari for downloading alternative browsers, such as Chrome or Firefox.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Products">Products</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Apple_Inc._products" class="mw-redirect" title="Timeline of Apple Inc. products">Timeline of Apple Inc. products</a>.</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mac">Mac</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mac_(computer)" title="Mac (computer)">Mac (computer)</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:242px;max-width:242px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:120px;max-width:120px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:118px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:M2_Macbook_Air_Midnight_model_-_1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="A MacBook Air, in midnight color, on a wooden desk." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/M2_Macbook_Air_Midnight_model_-_1.jpg/118px-M2_Macbook_Air_Midnight_model_-_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="118" height="118" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/M2_Macbook_Air_Midnight_model_-_1.jpg/177px-M2_Macbook_Air_Midnight_model_-_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/M2_Macbook_Air_Midnight_model_-_1.jpg/236px-M2_Macbook_Air_Midnight_model_-_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2160" data-file-height="2160" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">MacBook Air with M2 chip</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:118px;max-width:118px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:118px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:M1_iMac_blue_model_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="An thin iMac in blue color on a desk." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/M1_iMac_blue_model_%28cropped%29.jpg/116px-M1_iMac_blue_model_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="116" height="118" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/M1_iMac_blue_model_%28cropped%29.jpg/174px-M1_iMac_blue_model_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/M1_iMac_blue_model_%28cropped%29.jpg/232px-M1_iMac_blue_model_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2548" data-file-height="2592" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">iMac with M1 chip</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Macintosh, commonly known as Mac, is Apple's line of personal computers that use the company's proprietary <a href="/wiki/MacOS" title="MacOS">macOS</a> operating system. Personal computers were Apple's original business line, but as of the end of&#32;2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> they account for only about eight percent of the company's revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-10-K-Report-2023_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-10-K-Report-2023-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There are six Macintosh computer families in production:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/IMac" title="IMac">iMac</a>: Consumer all-in-one desktop computer, introduced in 1998.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mac_Mini" title="Mac Mini">Mac Mini</a>: Consumer sub-desktop computer, introduced in 2005.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/MacBook_Pro" title="MacBook Pro">MacBook Pro</a>: Professional notebook, introduced in 2006.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mac_Pro" title="Mac Pro">Mac Pro</a>: Professional workstation, introduced in 2006.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/MacBook_Air" title="MacBook Air">MacBook Air</a>: Consumer ultra-thin notebook, introduced in 2008.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mac_Studio" title="Mac Studio">Mac Studio</a>: Professional small form-factor workstation, introduced in 2022.</li></ul>
<p>Often described as a <a href="/wiki/Walled_garden_(technology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Walled garden (technology)">walled garden</a>, Macs use <a href="/wiki/Apple_silicon" title="Apple silicon">Apple silicon</a> chips, run the <a href="/wiki/MacOS" title="MacOS">macOS</a> operating system, and include Apple software like the <a href="/wiki/Safari_(web_browser)" title="Safari (web browser)">Safari</a> web browser, <a href="/wiki/IMovie" title="IMovie">iMovie</a> for home movie editing, <a href="/wiki/GarageBand" title="GarageBand">GarageBand</a> for music creation, and the <a href="/wiki/IWork" title="IWork">iWork</a> productivity suite. Apple also sells <a href="/wiki/Pro_apps_(Apple)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pro apps (Apple)">pro apps</a>: <a href="/wiki/Final_Cut_Pro" title="Final Cut Pro">Final Cut Pro</a> for video production, <a href="/wiki/Logic_Pro" title="Logic Pro">Logic Pro</a> for musicians and producers, and <a href="/wiki/Xcode" title="Xcode">Xcode</a> for software developers.
</p><p>Apple also sells a variety of accessories for Macs, including the <a href="/wiki/Pro_Display_XDR" title="Pro Display XDR">Pro Display XDR</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Studio_Display" title="Apple Studio Display">Apple Studio Display</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magic_Mouse" title="Magic Mouse">Magic Mouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magic_Trackpad" title="Magic Trackpad">Magic Trackpad</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Magic_Keyboard_(Mac)" title="Magic Keyboard (Mac)">Magic Keyboard</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="iPhone">iPhone</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:IPhone_15_6.1%22.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/IPhone_15_6.1%22.jpg/220px-IPhone_15_6.1%22.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/IPhone_15_6.1%22.jpg/330px-IPhone_15_6.1%22.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/IPhone_15_6.1%22.jpg/440px-IPhone_15_6.1%22.jpg 2x" data-file-width="8192" data-file-height="6144" /></a><figcaption>iPhone 15 (left) and iPhone 15 Pro (right)</figcaption></figure>
<p>The iPhone is Apple's line of <a href="/wiki/Smartphone" title="Smartphone">smartphones</a>, which run the <a href="/wiki/IOS" title="IOS">iOS</a> operating system. The <a href="/wiki/IPhone_(1st_generation)" title="IPhone (1st generation)">first iPhone</a> was unveiled by Steve Jobs on January 9, 2007. Since then, new models have been released every year. When it was introduced, its <a href="/wiki/Multi-touch" title="Multi-touch">multi-touch</a> screen was described as "revolutionary" and a "game-changer" for the mobile phone industry. The device has been credited with creating the <a href="/wiki/Mobile_app_development" title="Mobile app development">app economy</a>.
</p><p>iOS is one of the two largest smartphone platforms in the world alongside <a href="/wiki/Android_(operating_system)" title="Android (operating system)">Android</a>. The iPhone has generated large profits for the company, and is credited with helping to make Apple one of the world's most valuable publicly traded companies.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup> As of the end of&#32;2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the iPhone accounts for more than half of the company's revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-10-K-Report-2023_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-10-K-Report-2023-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="iPad">iPad</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/IPad" title="IPad">iPad</a></div>
<p>The iPad is Apple's line of <a href="/wiki/Tablet_computer" title="Tablet computer">tablets</a> which run <a href="/wiki/IPadOS" title="IPadOS">iPadOS</a>. The <a href="/wiki/IPad_(1st_generation)" title="IPad (1st generation)">first-generation iPad</a> was announced on January 27, 2010. The iPad is mainly marketed for consuming multimedia, creating art, working on documents, videoconferencing, and playing games. The iPad lineup consists of several base iPad models, and the smaller <a href="/wiki/IPad_Mini" title="IPad Mini">iPad Mini</a>, upgraded <a href="/wiki/IPad_Air" class="mw-redirect" title="IPad Air">iPad Air</a>, and high-end <a href="/wiki/IPad_Pro" title="IPad Pro">iPad Pro</a>. Apple has consistently improved the iPad's performance, with the <a href="/wiki/IPad_Pro" title="IPad Pro">iPad Pro</a> adopting the same <a href="/wiki/Apple_M1" title="Apple M1">M1</a> and <a href="/wiki/Apple_M2" title="Apple M2">M2</a> chips as the Mac; but the iPad still receives criticism for its limited OS.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As of September&#160;2020,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> Apple has sold more than 500&#160;million iPads, though sales peaked in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-500m_ipads_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-500m_ipads-184">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> The iPad still remains the most popular tablet computer by sales as of the second quarter of&#32;2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>,<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> and accounted for seven percent of the company's revenue as of the end of&#32;2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-10-K-Report-2023_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-10-K-Report-2023-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple sells several <a href="/wiki/List_of_iPad_accessories" title="List of iPad accessories">iPad accessories</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Pencil" title="Apple Pencil">Apple Pencil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smart_Keyboard" class="mw-redirect" title="Smart Keyboard">Smart Keyboard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smart_Keyboard_Folio" class="mw-redirect" title="Smart Keyboard Folio">Smart Keyboard Folio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magic_Keyboard_for_iPad" class="mw-redirect" title="Magic Keyboard for iPad">Magic Keyboard</a>, and several adapters.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_products">Other products</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:242px;max-width:242px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:132px;max-width:132px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:104px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_AirPods_Max_6.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Apple_AirPods_Max_6.jpg/130px-Apple_AirPods_Max_6.jpg" decoding="async" width="130" height="104" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Apple_AirPods_Max_6.jpg/195px-Apple_AirPods_Max_6.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Apple_AirPods_Max_6.jpg/260px-Apple_AirPods_Max_6.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5030" data-file-height="4024" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/AirPods_Max" title="AirPods Max">AirPods Max</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:106px;max-width:106px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:104px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Watch_Ultra_-_2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Apple_Watch_Ultra_-_2.jpg/104px-Apple_Watch_Ultra_-_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="104" height="104" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Apple_Watch_Ultra_-_2.jpg/156px-Apple_Watch_Ultra_-_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Apple_Watch_Ultra_-_2.jpg/208px-Apple_Watch_Ultra_-_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="576" data-file-height="576" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch_Ultra" title="Apple Watch Ultra">Apple Watch Ultra</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Apple makes several other products that it categorizes as "Wearables, Home and Accessories".<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup> These products include the <a href="/wiki/Apple_headphones" title="Apple headphones">AirPods</a> line of wireless headphones, <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV" title="Apple TV">Apple TV</a> digital media players, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch" title="Apple Watch">Apple Watch</a> smartwatches, <a href="/wiki/Beats_Electronics" title="Beats Electronics">Beats</a> headphones, <a href="/wiki/HomePod" title="HomePod">HomePod</a> smart speakers, and the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Vision_Pro" title="Apple Vision Pro">Vision Pro</a> mixed reality headset.
</p><p>As of the end of&#32;2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, this broad line of products comprises about ten percent of the company's revenues.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-10-K-Report-2023_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-10-K-Report-2023-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Services">Services</span></h3>
<p>Apple offers a broad line of services, including advertising in the App Store and Apple News app, the <a href="/wiki/AppleCare" class="mw-redirect" title="AppleCare">AppleCare</a>+ extended warranty plan, the <a href="/wiki/ICloud" title="ICloud">iCloud</a>+ cloud-based data storage service, payment services through the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Card" title="Apple Card">Apple Card</a> credit card and the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Pay" title="Apple Pay">Apple Pay</a> processing platform, digital content services including <a href="/wiki/Apple_Books" title="Apple Books">Apple Books</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fitness_(Apple)" title="Fitness (Apple)">Apple Fitness+</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Music" title="Apple Music">Apple Music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_News" title="Apple News">Apple News</a>+, <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV%2B" title="Apple TV+">Apple TV+</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/ITunes_Store" title="ITunes Store">iTunes Store</a>.
</p><p>As of the end of&#32;2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, services comprise about 22% of the company's revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-10-K-Report-2023_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-10-K-Report-2023-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> In 2019, Apple announced it would be making a concerted effort to expand its service revenues.<sup id="cite_ref-AppleVideoRevenue2_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AppleVideoRevenue2-187">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Marketing">Marketing</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Marketing_of_Apple_Inc." title="Marketing of Apple Inc.">Marketing of Apple Inc.</a></div><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Branding">Branding</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg/170px-Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg.png" decoding="async" width="170" height="198" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg/255px-Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg/340px-Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="858" data-file-height="1000" /></a><figcaption>The first official logo of Apple Inc. was used from 1977 to 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-logo_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-logo-188">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>According to Steve Jobs, the company's name was inspired by his visit to an apple farm while on a <a href="/wiki/Fruitarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Fruitarian">fruitarian</a> diet. Jobs thought the name "Apple" was "fun, spirited and not intimidating".<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup> Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak were fans of <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">the Beatles</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> but Apple Inc. had name and logo trademark issues with <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps" title="Apple Corps">Apple Corps Ltd.</a>, a multimedia company started by the Beatles in 1968. This resulted in a <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps_v_Apple_Computer" title="Apple Corps v Apple Computer">series of lawsuits</a> and tension between the two companies. These issues ended when they settled their lawsuit in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple's first logo, designed by <a href="/wiki/Ron_Wayne" class="mw-redirect" title="Ron Wayne">Ron Wayne</a>, depicts <a href="/wiki/Sir_Isaac_Newton" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir Isaac Newton">Sir Isaac Newton</a> sitting under an apple tree. It was almost immediately replaced by <a href="/wiki/Rob_Janoff" title="Rob Janoff">Rob Janoff</a>'s "rainbow Apple", the now-familiar rainbow-colored silhouette of an apple with a bite taken out of it.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> On August 27, 1999,<sup id="cite_ref-web.archive.org_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-web.archive.org-193">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup> Apple officially dropped the rainbow scheme and began to use monochromatic logos nearly identical in shape to the previous rainbow incarnation.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Apple_evangelist" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple evangelist">Apple evangelists</a> were actively engaged by the company at one time, but this was after the phenomenon had already been firmly established. Apple <a href="/wiki/Evangelism_marketing" title="Evangelism marketing">evangelist</a> <a href="/wiki/Guy_Kawasaki" title="Guy Kawasaki">Guy Kawasaki</a> has called the brand fanaticism "something that was stumbled upon,"<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> while Ive claimed in 2014 that "people have an incredibly personal relationship" with Apple's products.<sup id="cite_ref-Time_85-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-85">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/Fortune_(magazine)" title="Fortune (magazine)">Fortune</a></i> magazine named Apple the most admired company in the United States in 2008, and in the world from 2008 to 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup> On September 30, 2013, Apple surpassed <a href="/wiki/Coca-Cola" title="Coca-Cola">Coca-Cola</a> to become the world's most valuable brand in the <a href="/wiki/Omnicom_Group" title="Omnicom Group">Omnicom Group</a>'s "Best Global Brands" report.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Boston_Consulting_Group" title="Boston Consulting Group">Boston Consulting Group</a> has ranked Apple as the world's most innovative brand every year as of 2005<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As of January&#160;2021,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> 1.65 billion Apple products were in active use.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup> In February 2023, that number exceeded 2 billion devices.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Advertising">Advertising</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc._advertising" title="Apple Inc. advertising">Apple Inc. advertising</a></div>
<p>Apple's first slogan, "<a href="/wiki/Byte" title="Byte">Byte</a> into an Apple", was coined in the late 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup> From 1997 to 2002, the slogan "<a href="/wiki/Think_different" title="Think different">Think different</a>" was used in advertising campaigns, and is still closely associated with Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> Apple also has slogans for specific product lines—for example, "iThink, therefore iMac" was used in 1998 to promote the iMac,<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> and "Say hello to iPhone" has been used in iPhone advertisements.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> "Hello" was also used to introduce the original Macintosh, <a href="/wiki/Newton_(platform)" class="mw-redirect" title="Newton (platform)">Newton</a>, iMac ("hello (again)"), and iPod.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>From the introduction of the Macintosh in 1984, with the <a href="/wiki/1984_(television_commercial)" class="mw-redirect" title="1984 (television commercial)">1984 Super Bowl advertisement</a> to the more modern <a href="/wiki/Get_a_Mac" title="Get a Mac">Get a Mac</a> adverts, Apple has been recognized for its efforts toward effective advertising and marketing for its products. However, claims made by later campaigns <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc._advertising#Criticism" title="Apple Inc. advertising">were criticized</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> particularly the 2005 Power Mac ads.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> Apple's product advertisements gained significant attention as a result of their eye-popping graphics and catchy tunes.<sup id="cite_ref-Daily_News_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Daily_News-210">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> Musicians who benefited from an improved profile as a result of their songs being included on Apple advertisements include Canadian singer <a href="/wiki/Feist_(singer)" title="Feist (singer)">Feist</a> with the song "<a href="/wiki/1234_(Feist_song)" title="1234 (Feist song)">1234</a>" and <a href="/wiki/Yael_Naim" title="Yael Naim">Yael Naïm</a> with the song "<a href="/wiki/New_Soul" title="New Soul">New Soul</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-Daily_News_210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Daily_News-210">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Stores">Stores</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store" title="Apple Store">Apple Store</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg/220px-Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg/330px-Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg/440px-Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3084" data-file-height="2322" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Apple_Fifth_Avenue" title="Apple Fifth Avenue">Apple Fifth Avenue</a> is the flagship store in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Genius_Bar_Regentstreet_London.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Apple_Genius_Bar_Regentstreet_London.jpg/220px-Apple_Genius_Bar_Regentstreet_London.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="152" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Apple_Genius_Bar_Regentstreet_London.jpg/330px-Apple_Genius_Bar_Regentstreet_London.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Apple_Genius_Bar_Regentstreet_London.jpg/440px-Apple_Genius_Bar_Regentstreet_London.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="882" /></a><figcaption>Customers visit the <a href="/wiki/Genius_Bar" title="Genius Bar">Genius Bar</a> at Apple's <a href="/wiki/Regent_Street" title="Regent Street">Regent Street</a> store in 2006.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The first Apple Stores were originally opened as two locations in May 2001 by then-<a href="/wiki/CEO" class="mw-redirect" title="CEO">CEO</a> Steve Jobs,<sup id="cite_ref-First_stores_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-First_stores-92">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> after years of attempting but failing store-within-a-store concepts.<sup id="cite_ref-MacRumors_stores_94-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacRumors_stores-94">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> Seeing a need for improved retail presentation of the company's products, he began an effort in 1997 to revamp the retail program to get an improved relationship to consumers, and hired <a href="/wiki/Ron_Johnson_(businessman)" title="Ron Johnson (businessman)">Ron Johnson</a> in 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-MacRumors_stores_94-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacRumors_stores-94">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> Jobs relaunched Apple's online store in 1997,<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> and opened the first two physical stores in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-First_stores_92-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-First_stores-92">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> The media initially speculated that Apple would fail,<sup id="cite_ref-fortune-best-retailer_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fortune-best-retailer-95">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup> but its stores were highly successful, bypassing the sales numbers of competing nearby stores and within three years reached US$1 billion in annual sales, becoming the fastest retailer in history to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-fortune-best-retailer_95-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fortune-best-retailer-95">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Over the years, Apple has expanded the number of retail locations and its geographical coverage, with 499 stores across 22 countries worldwide as of December&#160;2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-96">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> Strong product sales have placed Apple among the top-tier retail stores, with sales over $16 billion globally in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-retail_army_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-retail_army-212">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> Apple Stores underwent a period of significant redesign, beginning in May 2016. This redesign included physical changes to the Apple Stores, such as open spaces and re-branded rooms, and changes in function to facilitate interaction between consumers and professionals.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Many Apple Stores are located inside shopping malls, but Apple has built several stand-alone "flagship" stores in high-profile locations.<sup id="cite_ref-MacRumors_stores_94-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacRumors_stores-94">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> It has been granted design <a href="/wiki/Patent" title="Patent">patents</a> and received architectural awards for its stores' designs and construction, specifically for its use of glass staircases and cubes.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup> The success of Apple Stores have had significant influence over other consumer electronics retailers, who have lost traffic, control and profits due to a perceived higher quality of service and products at Apple Stores.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> Due to the popularity of the brand, Apple receives a large number of job applications, many of which come from young workers.<sup id="cite_ref-retail_army_212-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-retail_army-212">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> Although Apple Store employees receive above-average pay, are offered money toward education and health care, and receive product discounts,<sup id="cite_ref-retail_army_212-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-retail_army-212">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> there are limited or no paths of career advancement.<sup id="cite_ref-retail_army_212-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-retail_army-212">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Market_power">Market power</span></h3>
<p>On March 16, 2020, France fined Apple €1.1 billion for colluding with two wholesalers to stifle competition and keep prices high by handicapping independent resellers. The arrangement created aligned prices for Apple products such as iPads and personal computers for about half the French retail market. According to the French regulators, the abuses occurred between 2005 and 2017 but were first discovered after a complaint by an independent reseller, eBizcuss, in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 13, 2020, <a href="/wiki/Epic_Games" title="Epic Games">Epic Games</a>, the maker of the popular game <i><a href="/wiki/Fortnite" title="Fortnite">Fortnite</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Epic_Games_v._Apple" title="Epic Games v. Apple">sued</a> both Apple and <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a> after <i>Fortnite</i> was removed from Apple's and Google's App stores. The lawsuits came after Apple and Google blocked the game after it introduced a direct payment system that bypassed the fees that Apple and Google had imposed.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup> In September 2020, Epic Games founded the <a href="/wiki/Coalition_for_App_Fairness" title="Coalition for App Fairness">Coalition for App Fairness</a> together with thirteen other companies, which aims for better conditions for the inclusion of apps in the app stores.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> Later, in December 2020, <a href="/wiki/Meta_Platforms" title="Meta Platforms">Facebook</a> agreed to assist Epic in their legal game against Apple, planning to support the company by providing materials and documents to Epic. Facebook had, however, stated that the company would not participate directly with the lawsuit, although did commit to helping with the discovery of evidence relating to the trial of 2021. In the months prior to their agreement, Facebook had been dealing with feuds against Apple relating to the prices of paid apps and privacy rule changes.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup> Head of ad products for Facebook Dan Levy commented, saying that "this is not really about privacy for them, this is about an attack on personalized ads and the consequences it's going to have on small-business owners," commenting on the full-page ads placed by Facebook in various newspapers in December 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Privacy">Privacy</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Prism-slide-8.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Prism-slide-8.jpg/220px-Prism-slide-8.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Prism-slide-8.jpg/330px-Prism-slide-8.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Prism-slide-8.jpg/440px-Prism-slide-8.jpg 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="525" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/PRISM_(surveillance_program)" class="mw-redirect" title="PRISM (surveillance program)">PRISM</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Clandestine_operation" title="Clandestine operation">clandestine</a> <a href="/wiki/Global_surveillance" title="Global surveillance">surveillance</a> program under which the <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Agency" title="National Security Agency">NSA</a> collects user data from companies like Facebook and Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Apple has publicly taken a pro-privacy stance, actively making privacy-conscious features and settings part of its conferences, promotional campaigns, and public image.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> With its <a href="/wiki/IOS_8" title="IOS 8">iOS 8</a> mobile operating system in 2014, the company started encrypting all contents of iOS devices through users' passcodes, making it impossible at the time for the company to provide customer data to law enforcement requests seeking such information.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> With the popularity rise of cloud storage solutions, Apple began a technique in 2016 to do <a href="/wiki/Deep_learning" title="Deep learning">deep learning</a> scans for facial data in photos on the user's local device and encrypting the content before uploading it to Apple's <a href="/wiki/ICloud" title="ICloud">iCloud</a> storage system.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> It also introduced "differential privacy", a way to collect crowdsourced data from many users, while keeping individual users anonymous, in a system that <i><a href="/wiki/Wired_(website)" class="mw-redirect" title="Wired (website)">Wired</a></i> described as "trying to learn as much as possible about a group while learning as little as possible about any individual in it".<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> Users are explicitly asked if they want to participate, and can actively opt-in or opt-out.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>However, Apple has aided law enforcement in criminal investigations by providing iCloud backups of users' devices,<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup> and the company's commitment to privacy has been questioned by its efforts to promote <a href="/wiki/Biometrics" title="Biometrics">biometric authentication</a> technology in its newer <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a> models, which do not have the same level of <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="United States Constitution">constitutional privacy</a> as a passcode in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>With Apple's release of an update to <a href="/wiki/IOS_14" title="IOS 14">iOS 14</a>, Apple required all developers of iPhone, iPad, and iPod Touch applications to directly ask iPhone users permission to track them. The feature, called "App Tracking Transparency", received heavy criticism from Facebook, whose primary business model revolves around the tracking of users' data and sharing such data with advertisers so users can see more relevant ads, a technique commonly known as <a href="/wiki/Targeted_advertising" title="Targeted advertising">targeted advertising</a>. After Facebook's measures, including purchasing full-page newspaper advertisements protesting App Tracking Transparency, Apple released the update in early 2021. A study by <a href="/wiki/Verizon_Communications" class="mw-redirect" title="Verizon Communications">Verizon</a> subsidiary Flurry Analytics reported only 4% of iOS users in the United States and 12% worldwide have opted into tracking.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Prior to the release of <a href="/wiki/IOS_15" title="IOS 15">iOS 15</a>, Apple announced new efforts at combating <a href="/wiki/Child_pornography" title="Child pornography">child sexual abuse material</a> on iOS and Mac platforms. Parents of minor <a href="/wiki/IMessage" title="IMessage">iMessage</a> users can now be alerted if their child sends or receives nude photographs. Additionally, on-device <a href="/wiki/Hash_function" title="Hash function">hashing</a> would take place on media destined for upload to iCloud, and hashes would be compared to a list of known abusive images provided by law enforcement; if enough matches were found, Apple would be alerted and authorities informed. The new features received praise from law enforcement and victims rights advocates, however privacy advocates, including the <a href="/wiki/Electronic_Frontier_Foundation" title="Electronic Frontier Foundation">Electronic Frontier Foundation</a>, condemned the new features as invasive and highly prone to abuse by authoritarian governments.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Ireland's <a href="/wiki/Data_Protection_Commission" class="mw-redirect" title="Data Protection Commission">Data Protection Commission</a> launched a privacy investigation to examine whether Apple complied with the EU's <a href="/wiki/GDPR" class="mw-redirect" title="GDPR">GDPR</a> law following an investigation into how the company processes personal data with targeted ads on its platform.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2019, security researcher <a href="/wiki/Brian_Krebs" title="Brian Krebs">Brian Krebs</a> discovered that the iPhone 11 Pro would still show the arrow indicator –signifying location services are being used– at the top of the screen while the main location services toggle is enabled, despite all individual location services being disabled. Krebs was unable to replicate this behavior on older models and when asking Apple for comment, he was told by Apple that "It is expected behavior that the Location Services icon appears in the status bar when Location Services is enabled. The icon appears for system services that do not have a switch in Settings."<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup>
Apple later further clarified that this behavior was to ensure compliance with <a href="/wiki/Ultra-wideband" title="Ultra-wideband">ultra-wideband</a> regulations in specific countries, a technology Apple started implementing in iPhones starting with iPhone 11 Pro, and emphasized that "the management of ultra wideband compliance and its use of location data is done entirely on the device and Apple is not collecting user location data." <a href="/w/index.php?title=Will_Strafach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Will Strafach (page does not exist)">Will Strafach</a>, an executive at security firm <a href="/wiki/Guardian_Firewall" title="Guardian Firewall">Guardian Firewall</a>, confirmed the lack of evidence that location data was sent off to a remote server. Apple promised to add a new toggle for this feature and in later iOS revisions Apple provided users with the option to tap on the location services indicator in Control Center to see which specific service is using the device's location.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to published reports by <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_News" title="Bloomberg News">Bloomberg News</a> on March 30, 2022, Apple turned over data such as phone numbers, physical addresses, and <a href="/wiki/IP_addresses" class="mw-redirect" title="IP addresses">IP addresses</a> to hackers posing as law enforcement officials using forged documents. The law enforcement requests sometimes included <a href="/wiki/Forged_signatures" class="mw-redirect" title="Forged signatures">forged signatures</a> of real or fictional officials. When asked about the allegations, an Apple representative referred the reporter to a section of the company policy for law enforcement guidelines, which stated, "We review every data request for legal sufficiency and use advanced systems and processes to validate law enforcement requests and detect abuse."<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporate_affairs">Corporate affairs</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_mergers_and_acquisitions_by_Apple" title="List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple">List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Braeburn_Capital" title="Braeburn Capital">Braeburn Capital</a>, and <a href="/wiki/FileMaker" title="FileMaker">FileMaker</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Business_trends">Business trends</span></h3>
<p>The key trends for Apple are, as of each financial year ending September 24:<sup id="cite_ref-:2_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-236">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:3_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-237">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Leadership">Leadership</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Senior_management">Senior management</span></h4>
<p>As of March&#160;16,&#32;2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the management of Apple Inc. includes:<sup id="cite_ref-aaplLeadership_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aaplLeadership-253">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chief_executive_officer" title="Chief executive officer">chief executive officer</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jeff_Williams_(Apple)" title="Jeff Williams (Apple)">Jeff Williams</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chief_operating_officer" title="Chief operating officer">chief operating officer</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Luca_Maestri" title="Luca Maestri">Luca Maestri</a> (senior vice president and <a href="/wiki/Chief_financial_officer" title="Chief financial officer">chief financial officer</a>)</li>
<li>Katherine L. Adams (senior vice president and general counsel)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Eddy_Cue" title="Eddy Cue">Eddy Cue</a> (senior vice president – Internet Software and Services)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Craig_Federighi" title="Craig Federighi">Craig Federighi</a> (senior vice president – Software Engineering)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_Giannandrea" title="John Giannandrea">John Giannandrea</a> (senior vice president – Machine Learning and AI Strategy)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Deirdre_O%27Brien" title="Deirdre O&#39;Brien">Deirdre O'Brien</a> (senior vice president – <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store" title="Apple Store">Retail</a> + People)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_Ternus" title="John Ternus">John Ternus</a> (senior vice president – Hardware Engineering)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Greg_Joswiak" title="Greg Joswiak">Greg Josiwak</a> (senior vice president – Worldwide Marketing)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Johny_Srouji" title="Johny Srouji">Johny Srouji</a> (senior vice president – Hardware Technologies)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sabih_Khan" title="Sabih Khan">Sabih Khan</a> (senior vice president – Operations)</li></ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Board_of_directors">Board of directors</span></h4>

</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Arthur_D._Levinson" title="Arthur D. Levinson">Arthur D. Levinson</a> (chairman)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a> (executive director and CEO)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/James_A._Bell" title="James A. Bell">James A. Bell</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Al_Gore" title="Al Gore">Al Gore</a></li>
