<li><a href="/wiki/Susan_Wagner" title="Susan Wagner">Susan Wagner</a></li></ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Previous_CEOs">Previous CEOs</span></h4>
<ol><li><a href="/wiki/Michael_Scott_(Apple)" title="Michael Scott (Apple)">Michael Scott</a> (1977–1981)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mike_Markkula" title="Mike Markkula">Mike Markkula</a> (1981–1983)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_Sculley" title="John Sculley">John Sculley</a> (1983–1993)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Michael_Spindler" title="Michael Spindler">Michael Spindler</a> (1993–1996)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gil_Amelio" title="Gil Amelio">Gil Amelio</a> (1996–1997)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a> (1997–2011)</li></ol>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ownership">Ownership</span></h3>
<p>As of December&#160;30,&#32;2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the largest shareholder of Apple were:<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/The_Vanguard_Group" title="The Vanguard Group">The Vanguard Group</a> (1,317,966,471 shares, 8.54%)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/BlackRock" title="BlackRock">BlackRock</a> (1,042,391,808 shares, 6.75%)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Berkshire_Hathaway" title="Berkshire Hathaway">Berkshire Hathaway</a> (905,560,000 shares, 5.86%)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/State_Street_Corporation" title="State Street Corporation">State Street Corporation</a> (586,052,057 shares, 3.80%)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Geode_Capital_Management" title="Geode Capital Management">Geode Capital Management</a> (300,822,623 shares, 1.95%)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Fidelity_Investments" title="Fidelity Investments">Fidelity Investments</a> (299,871,352 shares, 1.94%)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Morgan_Stanley" title="Morgan Stanley">Morgan Stanley</a> (217,961,227 shares, 1.41%)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/T._Rowe_Price" title="T. Rowe Price">T. Rowe Price</a> (210,827,097 shares, 1.37%)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Norges_Bank" title="Norges Bank">Norges Bank</a> (176,141,203 shares, 1.14%)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Northern_Trust" title="Northern Trust">Northern Trust</a> (162,115,200 shares, 1.05%)</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporate_culture">Corporate culture</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg/220px-Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="164" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg/330px-Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg/440px-Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1264" data-file-height="944" /></a><figcaption>Co-founder <a href="/wiki/Steve_Wozniak" title="Steve Wozniak">Steve Wozniak</a> and Macintosh engineer <a href="/wiki/Andy_Hertzfeld" title="Andy Hertzfeld">Andy Hertzfeld</a> attended the <a href="/wiki/Apple_User_Group_Connection" title="Apple User Group Connection">Apple User Group Connection</a> club in 1985.</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png/280px-Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="322" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png/420px-Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png/560px-Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png 2x" data-file-width="796" data-file-height="916" /></a><figcaption>These universities produced the most alumni who became Apple employees.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Apple is one of several highly successful companies founded in the 1970s that bucked the traditional notions of <a href="/wiki/Corporate_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Corporate culture">corporate culture</a>. Jobs often walked around the office barefoot even after Apple became a <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> company. By the time of the <a href="/wiki/1984_(advertisement)" title="1984 (advertisement)">"1984"</a> television advertisement, Apple's informal culture had become a key trait that differentiated it from its competitors.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> According to a 2011 report in <i><a href="/wiki/Fortune_(magazine)" title="Fortune (magazine)">Fortune</a></i>, this has resulted in a corporate culture more akin to a startup rather than a multinational corporation.<sup id="cite_ref-Fortune1_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fortune1-256">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> In a 2017 interview, Wozniak credited watching <i><a href="/wiki/Star_Trek" title="Star Trek">Star Trek</a></i> and attending <a href="/wiki/Star_Trek_convention" class="mw-redirect" title="Star Trek convention"><i>Star Trek</i> conventions</a> in his youth as inspiration for co-founding Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As the company has grown and been led by a series of differently opinionated chief executives, it has arguably lost some of its original character. Nonetheless, it has maintained a reputation for fostering individuality and excellence that reliably attracts talented workers, particularly after Jobs returned. Numerous Apple employees have stated that projects without Jobs's involvement often took longer than others.<sup id="cite_ref-cultofmacwork_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cultofmacwork-258">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Apple <a href="/wiki/Fellow#Industry_and_corporate_fellows" title="Fellow">Fellows</a> program awards employees for extraordinary technical or leadership contributions to <a href="/wiki/Personal_computing" class="mw-redirect" title="Personal computing">personal computing</a>. Recipients include <a href="/wiki/Bill_Atkinson" title="Bill Atkinson">Bill Atkinson</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-hertzfeld_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hertzfeld-259">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Steve_Capps" title="Steve Capps">Steve Capps</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rod_Holt" title="Rod Holt">Rod Holt</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-hertzfeld_259-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hertzfeld-259">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alan_Kay" title="Alan Kay">Alan Kay</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-yoyow_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yoyow-261">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Guy_Kawasaki" title="Guy Kawasaki">Guy Kawasaki</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-yoyow_261-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yoyow-261">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al_Alcorn" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Alcorn">Al Alcorn</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Don_Norman" title="Don Norman">Don Norman</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-yoyow_261-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yoyow-261">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rich_Page" title="Rich Page">Rich Page</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-hertzfeld_259-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hertzfeld-259">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Steve_Wozniak" title="Steve Wozniak">Steve Wozniak</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-hertzfeld_259-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hertzfeld-259">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Phil_Schiller" title="Phil Schiller">Phil Schiller</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>At Apple, employees are intended to be specialists who are not exposed to functions outside their area of expertise.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (November 2022)">needs update</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Jobs saw this as a means of having "best-in-class" employees in every role. For instance, <a href="/wiki/Ron_Johnson_(businessman)" title="Ron Johnson (businessman)">Ron Johnson</a>—Senior Vice President of Retail Operations until November 1, 2011—was responsible for site selection, in-store service, and store layout, yet had no control of the inventory in his stores. This was done by Tim Cook, who had a background in supply-chain management.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-266">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup> Apple is known for strictly enforcing accountability. Each project has a "directly responsible individual" or "DRI" in Apple jargon.<sup id="cite_ref-Fortune1_256-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fortune1-256">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup> As an example, when iOS senior vice president <a href="/wiki/Scott_Forstall" title="Scott Forstall">Scott Forstall</a> refused to sign Apple's official apology for numerous errors in the redesigned <a href="/wiki/Apple_Maps" title="Apple Maps">Maps app</a>, he was forced to resign.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup> Unlike other major U.S. companies, Apple provides a relatively simple compensation policy for executives that does not include perks enjoyed by other CEOs like country club fees or private use of company aircraft. The company typically grants stock options to executives every other year.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2015, Apple had 110,000&#160;full-time employees. This increased to 116,000&#160;full-time employees the next year, a notable hiring decrease, largely due to its first revenue decline. Apple does not specify how many of its employees work in retail, though its 2014 <a href="/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission" title="U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission">SEC</a> filing put the number at approximately half of its employee base.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup> In September 2017, Apple announced that it had over 123,000 full-time employees.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple has a strong culture of <a href="/wiki/Corporate_secrecy" class="mw-redirect" title="Corporate secrecy">corporate secrecy</a>, and has an anti-<a href="/wiki/News_leak" title="News leak">leak</a> Global Security team that recruits from the <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Agency" title="National Security Agency">National Security Agency</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">Federal Bureau of Investigation</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service" title="United States Secret Service">United States Secret Service</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2017, <a href="/wiki/Glassdoor" title="Glassdoor">Glassdoor</a> said Apple was the 48th best place to work, having originally entered at rank 19 in 2009, peaking at rank 10 in 2012, and falling down the ranks in subsequent years.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2023, <i>Bloomberg</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;s</span> Mark Gurman revealed the existence of Apple's Exploratory Design Group (XDG), which was working to add glucose monitoring to the Apple Watch. Gurman compared XDG to Alphabet's <a href="/wiki/X_Development" title="X Development">X "moonshot factory"</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Offices">Offices</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Apple_Park" title="Apple Park">Apple Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Campus" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Campus">Apple Campus</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_park_cupertino_2019.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Apple_park_cupertino_2019.jpg/220px-Apple_park_cupertino_2019.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Apple_park_cupertino_2019.jpg/330px-Apple_park_cupertino_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Apple_park_cupertino_2019.jpg/440px-Apple_park_cupertino_2019.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5464" data-file-height="3070" /></a><figcaption>Apple Park is the main headquarters in Cupertino.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Apple Inc.'s world corporate headquarters are located in <a href="/wiki/Cupertino,_California" title="Cupertino, California">Cupertino</a>, in the middle of California's <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a>, at Apple Park, a massive circular <a href="/wiki/Groundscraper" title="Groundscraper">groundscraper</a> building with a <a href="/wiki/Circumference" title="Circumference">circumference</a> of one mile (1.6&#160;km). The building opened in April 2017 and houses more than 12,000 employees. Apple co-founder <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a> wanted Apple Park to look less like a <a href="/wiki/Business_park" title="Business park">business park</a> and more like a nature refuge, and personally appeared before the Cupertino City Council in June 2011 to make the proposal, in his final public appearance before his death.
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Headquarters_in_Cupertino.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Apple_Headquarters_in_Cupertino.jpg/220px-Apple_Headquarters_in_Cupertino.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="153" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Apple_Headquarters_in_Cupertino.jpg/330px-Apple_Headquarters_in_Cupertino.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Apple_Headquarters_in_Cupertino.jpg/440px-Apple_Headquarters_in_Cupertino.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2885" data-file-height="2008" /></a><figcaption>The original Apple Campus has the street address 1 Infinite Loop, Sunnyvale, California.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Apple also operates from the Apple Campus (also known by its address, 1 Infinite Loop), a grouping of six buildings in Cupertino that total 850,000 square feet (79,000&#160;m<sup>2</sup>) located about 1 mile (1.6&#160;km) to the west of Apple Park.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> The Apple Campus was the company's headquarters from its opening in 1993, until the opening of Apple Park in 2017. The buildings, located at 1–6 <a href="/wiki/Apple_Infinite_Loop" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Infinite Loop">Infinite Loop</a>, are arranged in a circular pattern around a central <a href="/wiki/Green_infrastructure" title="Green infrastructure">green space</a>, in a design that has been compared to that of a <a href="/wiki/University" title="University">university</a>.
</p><p>In addition to Apple Park and the Apple Campus, Apple occupies an additional thirty office buildings scattered throughout the city of Cupertino, including three buildings as prior headquarters: Stephens Creek Three from 1977 to 1978, Bandley One from 1978 to 1982, and Mariani One from 1982 to 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> In total, Apple occupies almost 40% of the available office space in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple's headquarters for Europe, the Middle East and Africa (EMEA) are located in <a href="/wiki/Cork_(city)" title="Cork (city)">Cork</a> in the south of <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a>, called the Hollyhill campus.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup> The facility, which opened in 1980, houses 5,500 people and was Apple's first location outside of the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> Apple's international sales and distribution arms operate out of the campus in Cork.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple has two campuses near Austin, Texas: a 216,000-square-foot (20,100&#160;m<sup>2</sup>) campus opened in 2014 houses 500 engineers who work on <a href="/wiki/Apple_silicon" title="Apple silicon">Apple silicon</a><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup> and a 1.1-million-square-foot (100,000&#160;m<sup>2</sup>) campus opened in 2021 where 6,000 people work in technical support, supply chain management, online store curation, and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Maps" title="Apple Maps">Apple Maps</a> data management.
</p><p>The company also has several other locations in Boulder, Colorado; Culver City, California; Herzliya (Israel), London, New York, Pittsburgh, San Diego, and Seattle that each employ hundreds of people.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Litigation">Litigation</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Litigation_involving_Apple_Inc." title="Litigation involving Apple Inc.">Litigation involving Apple Inc.</a></div>
<p>Apple has been a participant in various legal proceedings and claims since it began operation.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> In particular, Apple is known for and promotes itself as actively and aggressively enforcing its intellectual property interests. Some litigation examples include <i><a href="/wiki/Apple_v._Samsung" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple v. Samsung">Apple v. Samsung</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Apple_v._Microsoft" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple v. Microsoft">Apple v. Microsoft</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Motorola_Mobility_v._Apple_Inc." title="Motorola Mobility v. Apple Inc.">Motorola Mobility v. Apple Inc.</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps_v._Apple_Computer" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Corps v. Apple Computer">Apple Corps v. Apple Computer</a></i>. Apple has also had to defend itself against charges on numerous occasions of violating intellectual property rights. Most have been dismissed in the courts as <a href="/wiki/Shell_corporation" title="Shell corporation">shell companies</a> known as <a href="/wiki/Patent_troll" title="Patent troll">patent trolls</a>, with no evidence of actual use of <a href="/wiki/Patent" title="Patent">patents</a> in question.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup> On December 21, 2016, Nokia announced that in the U.S. and Germany, it has filed a suit against Apple, claiming that the latter's products infringe on Nokia's patents.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> Most recently, in November 2017, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_International_Trade_Commission" title="United States International Trade Commission">United States International Trade Commission</a> announced an investigation into allegations of patent infringement in regards to Apple's remote desktop technology; Aqua Connect, a company that builds remote desktop software, has claimed that Apple infringed on two of its patents.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup> In January 2022, <a href="/wiki/Ericsson" title="Ericsson">Ericsson</a> sued Apple over payment of royalty of <a href="/wiki/5G" title="5G">5G</a> technology.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Finances">Finances</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_mergers_and_acquisitions_by_Apple" title="List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple">List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple</a></div>
<p>Apple is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_technology_companies_by_revenue" title="List of largest technology companies by revenue">world's largest technology company</a> by revenue, the world's largest technology company by <a href="/wiki/Asset" title="Asset">total assets</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Mobile_phone#By_manufacturer" title="Mobile phone">world's second-largest mobile phone manufacturer</a> after <a href="/wiki/Samsung" title="Samsung">Samsung</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In its fiscal year ending in September 2011, Apple Inc. reported a total of $108&#160;billion in annual revenues—a significant increase from its 2010 revenues of $65&#160;billion—and nearly $82&#160;billion in <a href="/wiki/Reserve_(accounting)" title="Reserve (accounting)">cash reserves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup> On March 19, 2012, Apple announced plans for a $2.65-per-share <a href="/wiki/Dividend" title="Dividend">dividend</a> beginning in fourth quarter of 2012, per approval by their board of directors.<sup id="cite_ref-dividendfaq_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dividendfaq-291">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The company's worldwide annual revenue in 2013 totaled $170&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> In May 2013, Apple entered the top ten of the <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500"><i>Fortune</i> 500</a> list of companies for the first time, rising 11 places above its 2012 ranking to take the sixth position.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup> As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Apple has around US$234&#160;billion of cash and marketable securities, of which 90% is located outside the United States for tax purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-b200_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b200-294">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple amassed 65% of all profits made by the eight largest worldwide smartphone manufacturers in quarter one of 2014, according to a report by <a href="/wiki/Canaccord_Genuity" title="Canaccord Genuity">Canaccord Genuity</a>. In the first quarter of 2015, the company garnered 92% of all earnings.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On April 30, 2017, <i>The Wall Street Journal</i> reported that Apple had <a href="/wiki/Cash_reserve" class="mw-redirect" title="Cash reserve">cash reserves</a> of $250&#160;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> officially confirmed by Apple as specifically $256.8&#160;billion a few days later.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As of August&#160;3,&#32;2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Apple was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_corporations_by_market_capitalization" class="mw-redirect" title="List of corporations by market capitalization">largest publicly traded corporation in the world by market capitalization</a>. On August 2, 2018, Apple became the first publicly traded U.S. company to reach a $1&#160;trillion market value.<sup id="cite_ref-1t-CNBC_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1t-CNBC-298">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-1t-Guardian_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1t-Guardian-299">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup> Apple was ranked No. 4 on the 2018 <i>Fortune</i> 500 rankings of the largest United States corporations by total revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2022, Apple reported an 11% decline in Q3 profits compared to 2021. Its revenue in the same period rose 2% year-on-year to $83 billion, though this figure was also lower than in 2021, where the increase was at 36%. The general downturn is reportedly caused by the slowing global economy and supply chain disruptions in China.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2023, Apple reported a decline in its sales for the first quarter of 2023. Compared to that of 2022, revenue for 2023 fell by 3%. This is Apple's second consecutive quarter of sales decline. This fall is attributed to the slowing economy and consumers putting off purchases of iPads and computers due to increased pricing. However, iPhone sales held up with a year-on-year increase of 1.5%. According to Apple, demands for such devices were strong, particularly in Latin America and South Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Taxes">Taxes</span></h3>
<p>Apple has created subsidiaries in low-tax places such as <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/British_Virgin_Islands" title="British Virgin Islands">British Virgin Islands</a> to cut the taxes it pays around the world. According to <i>The New York Times</i>, in the 1980s Apple was among the first tech companies to designate overseas salespeople in high-tax countries in a manner that allowed the company to sell on behalf of low-tax subsidiaries on other continents, sidestepping income taxes. In the late 1980s, Apple was a pioneer of an accounting technique known as the "<a href="/wiki/Double_Irish_with_a_Dutch_sandwich" class="mw-redirect" title="Double Irish with a Dutch sandwich">Double Irish with a Dutch sandwich</a>", which reduces taxes by routing profits through Irish subsidiaries and the Netherlands and then to the Caribbean.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/British_Conservative_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="British Conservative Party">British Conservative Party</a> Member of Parliament <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Elphicke" title="Charlie Elphicke">Charlie Elphicke</a> published research on October 30, 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup> which showed that some multinational companies, including Apple Inc., were making billions of pounds of profit in the UK, but were paying an effective tax rate to the UK Treasury of only 3 percent, well below standard <a href="/wiki/Corporate_tax" title="Corporate tax">corporate tax</a> rates. He followed this research by calling on the <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_of_the_Exchequer" title="Chancellor of the Exchequer">Chancellor of the Exchequer</a> <a href="/wiki/George_Osborne" title="George Osborne">George Osborne</a> to force these multinationals, which also included <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Coca-Cola_Company" title="The Coca-Cola Company">The Coca-Cola Company</a>, to state the effective rate of tax they pay on their UK revenues. Elphicke also said that government contracts should be withheld from multinationals who do not pay their fair share of UK tax.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a <a href="/wiki/United_States_Senate" title="United States Senate">US Senate</a> report on the company's offshore tax structure concluded in May 2013, Apple has held billions of dollars in profits in Irish subsidiaries to pay little or no taxes to any government by using an unusual global tax structure.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup> The main subsidiary, a holding company that includes Apple's retail stores throughout Europe, has not paid any corporate income tax in the last five years. "Apple has exploited a difference between Irish and U.S. tax residency rules", the report said.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On May 21, 2013, Apple CEO <a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a> defended his company's tax tactics at a Senate hearing.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple says that it is the single largest taxpayer in the U.S., with an <a href="/wiki/Tax_rate" title="Tax rate">effective tax rate</a> of approximately of 26% as of Q2 <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_year" title="Fiscal year">FY</a>2016.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup> In an interview with the German newspaper <i><a href="/wiki/Frankfurter_Allgemeine_Zeitung" title="Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung">FAZ</a></i> in October 2017, Tim Cook stated that Apple was the biggest taxpayer worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2016, after <a href="/wiki/Ireland_v_Commission" class="mw-redirect" title="Ireland v Commission">a two-year investigation</a>, the European Commission claimed that Apple's use of a hybrid <a href="/wiki/Double_Irish_arrangement" title="Double Irish arrangement">Double Irish</a> tax arrangement constituted "illegal state aid" from Ireland, and ordered Apple to pay 13 billion euros ($14.5 billion) in unpaid taxes, the largest corporate tax fine in history. This was later annulled, after the <a href="/wiki/General_Court_(European_Union)" title="General Court (European Union)">European General Court</a> ruled that the commission had provided insufficient evidence.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-IT11_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IT11-313">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup> In 2018, Apple repatriated $285 billion to America, resulting in a $38 billion tax payment spread over the following eight years.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Charity">Charity</span></h3>
<p>Apple is a partner of <a href="/wiki/Product_Red" title="Product Red">Product Red</a>, a fundraising campaign for <a href="/wiki/HIV/AIDS" title="HIV/AIDS">AIDS</a> charity. In November 2014, Apple arranged for all <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" class="mw-redirect" title="App Store (iOS)">App Store</a> revenue in a two-week period to go to the fundraiser,<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup> generating more than US$20&#160;million,<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup> and in March 2017, it released an <a href="/wiki/IPhone_7" title="IPhone 7">iPhone 7</a> with a red color finish.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple contributes financially to fundraisers in times of natural disasters. In November 2012, it donated $2.5&#160;million to the <a href="/wiki/American_Red_Cross" title="American Red Cross">American Red Cross</a> to aid relief efforts after <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy" title="Hurricane Sandy">Hurricane Sandy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup> and in 2017 it donated $5&#160;million to relief efforts for both <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Irma" title="Hurricane Irma">Hurricane Irma</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Harvey" title="Hurricane Harvey">Hurricane Harvey</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup> and for the <a href="/wiki/2017_Central_Mexico_earthquake" class="mw-redirect" title="2017 Central Mexico earthquake">2017 Central Mexico earthquake</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup> The company has used its <a href="/wiki/ITunes" title="ITunes">iTunes</a> platform to encourage donations in the wake of environmental disasters and humanitarian crises, such as the <a href="/wiki/2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="2010 Haiti earthquake">2010 Haiti earthquake</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami">2011 Japan earthquake</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Typhoon_Haiyan" title="Typhoon Haiyan">Typhoon Haiyan</a> in the Philippines in November 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/2015_European_migrant_crisis" title="2015 European migrant crisis">2015 European migrant crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup> Apple emphasizes that it does not incur any processing or other fees for iTunes donations, sending 100% of the payments directly to relief efforts, though it also acknowledges that the Red Cross does not receive any personal information on the users donating and that the payments may not be tax deductible.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On April 14, 2016, Apple and the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">World Wide Fund for Nature</a> (WWF) announced that they have engaged in a partnership to, "help protect life on our planet." Apple released a special page in the <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" class="mw-redirect" title="App Store (iOS)">iTunes App Store</a>, Apps for Earth. In the arrangement, Apple has committed that through April 24, WWF will receive 100% of the proceeds from the applications participating in the App Store via both the purchases of any paid apps and the In-App Purchases. Apple and WWF's Apps for Earth campaign raised more than $8&#160;million in total proceeds to support WWF's conservation work. WWF announced the results at WWDC 2016 in San Francisco.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, Apple's CEO Cook announced that the company will be donating "millions" of masks to health workers in the United States and Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 13, 2021, Apple announced a $100 million Racial Equity and Justice Initiative to help combat <a href="/wiki/Institutional_racism" title="Institutional racism">institutional racism</a> worldwide after the 2020 <a href="/wiki/Murder_of_George_Floyd" title="Murder of George Floyd">murder of George Floyd</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Doubles_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Doubles-328">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup> In June 2023, Apple announced doubling this and then distributed more than $200 million to support organizations focused on education, economic growth, and criminal justice. Half is philanthropic grants and half is centered on equity.<sup id="cite_ref-Doubles_328-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Doubles-328">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_impact_of_Apple" title="Environmental impact of Apple">Environmental impact of Apple</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097763485"><table class="box-Summarize plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><span typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/80px-Edit-clear.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="48" data-file-height="48" /></span></span></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span"><b>This section should include a better summary of, or be better summarized in <a href="/wiki/Environmental_impact_of_Apple" title="Environmental impact of Apple">Environmental impact of Apple</a>.</b><span class="hide-when-compact"> See <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Summary_style" title="Wikipedia:Summary style">Wikipedia:Summary style</a> for information on how to  incorporate it into this article's main text, or the main text of another article.</span>  <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">January 2023</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Apple_Energy">Apple Energy</span></h3>
<p>Apple Energy, LLC is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Apple Inc. that sells <a href="/wiki/Solar_energy" title="Solar energy">solar energy</a>. As of June&#160;6,&#32;2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Apple's solar farms in California and Nevada have been declared to provide 217.9 megawatts of solar generation capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup> Apple has received regulatory approval to construct a <a href="/wiki/Landfill_gas_utilization" title="Landfill gas utilization">landfill gas energy plant</a> in <a href="/wiki/North_Carolina" title="North Carolina">North Carolina</a> to use the <a href="/wiki/Methane_emissions" title="Methane emissions">methane emissions</a> to generate electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup> Apple's North Carolina data center is already powered entirely by renewable sources.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy_and_resources">Energy and resources</span></h3>
<p>In 2010, <a href="/wiki/Climate_Counts" title="Climate Counts">Climate Counts</a>, a nonprofit organization dedicated to directing consumers toward the greenest companies, gave Apple a score of 52 points out of a possible 100, which puts Apple in their top category "Striding".<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">&#91;332&#93;</a></sup> This was an increase from May 2008, when Climate Counts only gave Apple 11 points out of 100, which placed the company last among electronics companies, at which time Climate Counts also labeled Apple with a "stuck icon", adding that Apple at the time was "a choice to avoid for the climate-conscious consumer".<sup id="cite_ref-iwclimate_335-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iwclimate-335">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Following a <a href="/wiki/Greenpeace" title="Greenpeace">Greenpeace</a> protest, Apple released a statement on April 17, 2012, committing to ending its use of coal and shifting to 100% renewable clean energy.<sup id="cite_ref-After_Greenpeace_Protests,_Apple_Promises_to_Dump_Coal_Power_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-After_Greenpeace_Protests,_Apple_Promises_to_Dump_Coal_Power-336">&#91;334&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Powering_Our_Facilities_with_Clean,_Renewable_Energy_337-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Powering_Our_Facilities_with_Clean,_Renewable_Energy-337">&#91;335&#93;</a></sup> By 2013, Apple was using <a href="/wiki/100%25_renewable_energy" title="100% renewable energy">100% renewable energy</a> to power their data centers. Overall, 75% of the company's power came from clean renewable sources.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2015, Greenpeace evaluated the state of the Green Internet and commended Apple on their environmental practices saying, "Apple's commitment to renewable energy has helped set a new bar for the industry, illustrating in very concrete terms that a 100% renewable Internet is within its reach, and providing several models of intervention for other companies that want to build a sustainable Internet."<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Apple states that 100% of its U.S. operations run on <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a>, 100% of Apple's <a href="/wiki/Data_center" title="Data center">data centers</a> run on renewable energy and 93% of Apple's global operations run on renewable energy.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup> However, the facilities are connected to the local <a href="/wiki/Electrical_grid" title="Electrical grid">grid</a> which usually contains a mix of fossil and renewable sources, so Apple <a href="/wiki/Carbon_offset" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon offset">carbon offsets</a> its electricity use.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Electronic_Product_Environmental_Assessment_Tool" title="Electronic Product Environmental Assessment Tool">Electronic Product Environmental Assessment Tool</a> (EPEAT) allows consumers to see the effect a product has on the environment. Each product receives a Gold, Silver, or Bronze rank depending on its efficiency and sustainability. Every Apple <a href="/wiki/Tablet_computer" title="Tablet computer">tablet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laptop" title="Laptop">notebook</a>, <a href="/wiki/Desktop_computer" title="Desktop computer">desktop computer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Computer_monitor" title="Computer monitor">display</a> that EPEAT ranks achieves a Gold rating, the highest possible. Although Apple's data centers recycle water 35 times,<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup> the increased activity in retail, corporate and data centers also increase the amount of water use to 573&#160;million&#160;US&#160;gal (2.2&#160;million&#160;m<sup>3</sup>) in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During an event on March 21, 2016, Apple provided a status update on its environmental initiative to be 100% renewable in all of its worldwide operations. <a href="/wiki/Lisa_P._Jackson" title="Lisa P. Jackson">Lisa P. Jackson</a>, Apple's vice president of Environment, Policy and Social Initiatives who reports directly to CEO, Tim Cook, announced that as of March&#160;2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, 93% of Apple's worldwide operations are powered with renewable energy. Also featured was the company's efforts to use sustainable paper in their product packaging; 99% of all paper used by Apple in the product packaging comes from <a href="/wiki/Post-consumer" class="mw-redirect" title="Post-consumer">post-consumer</a> <a href="/wiki/Recycle" class="mw-redirect" title="Recycle">recycled</a> paper or sustainably managed forests, as the company continues its move to all paper packaging for all of its products.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">&#91;342&#93;</a></sup> Apple working in partnership with <a href="/wiki/The_Conservation_Fund" title="The Conservation Fund">Conservation Fund</a>, have preserved 36,000 acres of working forests in <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">Maine</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Carolina" title="North Carolina">North Carolina</a>. Another partnership announced is with the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">World Wildlife Fund</a> to preserve up to 1,000,000 acres (4,000&#160;km<sup>2</sup>) of forests in China. Featured was the company's installation of a 40 <a href="/wiki/Megawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Megawatt">MW</a> <a href="/wiki/Solar_power" title="Solar power">solar power</a> plant in the <a href="/wiki/Sichuan" title="Sichuan">Sichuan</a> province of <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> that was tailor-made to coexist with the indigenous yaks that eat hay produced on the land, by raising the panels to be several feet off of the ground so the yaks and their feed would be unharmed grazing beneath the array. This installation alone compensates for more than all of the energy used in Apple's Stores and Offices in the whole of China, negating the company's energy carbon footprint in the country. In <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, Apple has worked with the Singaporean government to cover the rooftops of 800 buildings in the city-state with solar panels allowing Apple's Singapore operations to be run on 100% renewable energy. Liam was introduced to the world, an advanced robotic disassembler and sorter designed by Apple Engineers in California specifically for recycling outdated or broken iPhones. Reuses and recycles parts from traded in products.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple announced on August 16, 2016, that Lens Technology, one of its major suppliers in China, has committed to power all its <a href="/wiki/Glass_production" title="Glass production">glass production</a> for Apple with 100 percent renewable energy by 2018. The commitment is a large step in Apple's efforts to help manufacturers lower their carbon footprint in China.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup> Apple also announced that all 14 of its final assembly sites in China are now compliant with <a href="/wiki/UL_(safety_organization)" title="UL (safety organization)">UL's</a> Zero Waste to Landfill validation. The standard, which started in January 2015, certifies that all manufacturing waste is <a href="/wiki/Reuse" title="Reuse">reused</a>, <a href="/wiki/Recycled" class="mw-redirect" title="Recycled">recycled</a>, <a href="/wiki/Compost" title="Compost">composted</a>, or converted into energy (when necessary). Since the program began, nearly 140,000 metric tons of waste have been diverted from <a href="/wiki/Landfill" title="Landfill">landfills</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On July 21, 2020, Apple announced its plan to become <a href="/wiki/Carbon_neutrality" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon neutrality">carbon neutral</a> across its entire business, manufacturing supply chain, and product life cycle by 2030. In the next 10 years, Apple will try to lower emissions with a series of innovative actions, including: low carbon product design, expanding energy efficiency, renewable energy, process and material innovations, and carbon removal.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2021, Apple said that it had started a $200 million fund in order to combat climate change by removing 1 million metric tons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere each year.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2022, the NewClimate Institute, a German environmental policy think tank, published a survey evaluating the transparency and progress of the climate strategies and carbon neutrality pledges announced by 25 major companies in the United States that found that Apple's carbon neutrality pledge and climate strategy was unsubstantiated and misleading.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In Russia, in 2022, the company's revenue amounted to 85 billion rubles.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2023, Apple announced it was dropping leather from its product lines, citing the material's "significant carbon footprint".<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup> The move earned Apple a 2023 Company of the Year award from <a href="/wiki/People_for_the_Ethical_Treatment_of_Animals" title="People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals">PETA</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Toxins">Toxins</span></h3>
<p>Following further campaigns by Greenpeace,<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup> in 2008, Apple became the first electronics manufacturer to eliminate all <a href="/wiki/Polyvinyl_chloride" title="Polyvinyl chloride">polyvinyl chloride</a> (PVC) and <a href="/wiki/Brominated_flame_retardant" title="Brominated flame retardant">brominated flame retardants</a> (BFRs) in its complete product line.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup> In June 2007, Apple began replacing the <a href="/wiki/Cold_cathode" title="Cold cathode">cold cathode</a> fluorescent lamp (CCFL) backlit <a href="/wiki/LCD" class="mw-redirect" title="LCD">LCD</a> displays in its computers with <a href="/wiki/Mercury_(element)" title="Mercury (element)">mercury</a>-free <a href="/wiki/LED-backlit_LCD_display" class="mw-redirect" title="LED-backlit LCD display">LED-backlit LCD displays</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arsenic" title="Arsenic">arsenic</a>-free glass, starting with the upgraded <a href="/wiki/MacBook_Pro" title="MacBook Pro">MacBook Pro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-environmental-news_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-environmental-news-356">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-agreenapple_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agreenapple-357">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-green_notebooks_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-green_notebooks-358">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup> Apple offers comprehensive and transparent information about the <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide_equivalent" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon dioxide equivalent">CO<sub>2</sub>e</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="Greenhouse gas emissions">emissions</a>, materials, and <a href="/wiki/Electric_energy_consumption" title="Electric energy consumption">electrical usage</a> concerning every product they currently produce or have sold in the past (and which they have enough data needed to produce the report), in their portfolio on their homepage. Allowing consumers to make informed purchasing decisions on the products they offer for sale.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup> In June 2009, Apple's <a href="/wiki/IPhone_3GS" title="IPhone 3GS">iPhone 3GS</a> was free of PVC, arsenic, and BFRs.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-environmental-news_356-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-environmental-news-356">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup> All Apple products now have mercury-free LED-backlit LCD displays, arsenic-free glass, and non-PVC cables. All Apple products have EPEAT Gold status and beat the latest Energy Star guidelines in each product's respective regulatory category.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-environmental-news_356-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-environmental-news-356">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2011, Apple was featured in Greenpeace's Guide to Greener Electronics, which ranks electronics manufacturers on sustainability, <a href="/wiki/Climate_and_energy" title="Climate and energy">climate and energy</a> policy, and how "green" their products are. The company ranked fourth of fifteen electronics companies (moving up five places from the previous year) with a score of 4.6/10.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup> Greenpeace praised Apple's <a href="/wiki/Sustainability_metrics_and_indices" title="Sustainability metrics and indices">sustainability</a>, noting that the company exceeded its 70% global recycling goal in 2010. Apple continues to score well on product ratings, with all of their products now being free of PVC plastic and BFRs. However, the guide criticized Apple on the Energy criteria for not seeking external verification of its greenhouse gas emissions data, and for not setting any targets to reduce emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup> In January 2012, Apple requested that its cable maker, Volex, begin producing <a href="/wiki/Low_smoke_zero_halogen" title="Low smoke zero halogen">halogen-free</a> <a href="/wiki/USB" title="USB">USB</a> and power cables.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Green_bonds">Green bonds</span></h3>
<p>In February 2016, Apple issued a <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$1.5</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>billion <a href="/wiki/Green_bond" title="Green bond">green bond</a> (climate bond), the first ever of its kind by a U.S. tech company. The green bond proceeds are dedicated to the financing of environmental projects.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Supply_chain">Supply chain</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple_supply_chain" title="Apple supply chain">Apple supply chain</a></div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097763485"><table class="box-Summarize plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><span typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/80px-Edit-clear.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="48" data-file-height="48" /></span></span></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span"><b>This section should include a better summary of, or be better summarized in <a href="/wiki/Apple_supply_chain" title="Apple supply chain">Apple supply chain</a>.</b><span class="hide-when-compact"> See <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Summary_style" title="Wikipedia:Summary style">Wikipedia:Summary style</a> for information on how to  incorporate it into this article's main text, or the main text of another article.</span>  <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">January 2023</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Apple products were made in America in Apple-owned factories until the late 1990s; however, as a result of <a href="/wiki/Outsourcing" title="Outsourcing">outsourcing</a> initiatives in the 2000s, almost all of its manufacturing is now handled abroad. According to a report by <i>The New York Times</i>, Apple insiders "believe the vast scale of overseas factories, as well as the flexibility, diligence and industrial skills of foreign workers, have so outpaced their American counterparts that '<a href="/wiki/Made_in_USA" title="Made in USA">Made in the USA</a>' is no longer a viable option for most Apple products".<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The company's manufacturing, procurement, and logistics enable it to execute massive product launches without having to maintain large, profit-sapping inventories. In 2011, Apple's profit margins were 40 percent, compared with between 10 and 20 percent for most other hardware companies. Cook's catchphrase to describe his focus on the company's operational arm is: "Nobody wants to buy sour milk."<sup id="cite_ref-supply_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-supply-368">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2017, the company announced a $1 billion funding project for "advanced manufacturing" in the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup> and subsequently invested $200&#160;million in <a href="/wiki/Corning_Inc." title="Corning Inc.">Corning Inc.</a>, a manufacturer of toughened <a href="/wiki/Gorilla_Glass" title="Gorilla Glass">Gorilla Glass</a> technology used in its <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a> devices.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup> The following December, Apple's chief operating officer, <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Williams_(Apple)" title="Jeff Williams (Apple)">Jeff Williams</a>, told <i>CNBC</i> that the "$1 billion" amount was "absolutely not" the final limit on its spending, elaborating that "We're not thinking in terms of a fund limit... We're thinking about, where are the opportunities across the U.S. to help nurture companies that are making the advanced technology— and the advanced manufacturing that goes with that— that quite frankly is essential to our innovation."<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Apple uses components from 43 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> The majority of assembling is done by Taiwanese <a href="/wiki/Original_design_manufacturer" title="Original design manufacturer">original design manufacturer</a> firms <a href="/wiki/Foxconn" title="Foxconn">Foxconn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pegatron" title="Pegatron">Pegatron</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wistron" title="Wistron">Wistron</a> and <a href="/wiki/Compal_Electronics" title="Compal Electronics">Compal Electronics</a> with factories mostly located inside China,<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> but also Brazil,<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup> and India.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/TSMC" title="TSMC">Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.</a>, (TSMC) is a <a href="/wiki/Foundry_model" title="Foundry model">pure-play semiconductor</a> manufacturing company. They make the majority of Apple's smartphone SoCs, with <a href="/wiki/Samsung_Semiconductor" class="mw-redirect" title="Samsung Semiconductor">Samsung Semiconductor</a>, playing a minority role.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> Apple, alone accounted for over 25% of TSMC's total income in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup> Apple's Bionic lineup of smartphone SoCs, are currently made exclusively by TSMC<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup> from the A11 bionic onward, previously manufacturing was shared with Samsung. The <a href="/wiki/Apple_M_series" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple M series">M series</a> of Apple SoC for consumer computers and tablets is made by TSMC.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Mac's early history Apple generally refused to adopt prevailing industry standards for hardware, instead creating their own.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup> This trend was largely reversed in the late 1990s, beginning with Apple's adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Peripheral_Component_Interconnect" title="Peripheral Component Interconnect">PCI</a> bus in the <a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh_7500" title="Power Macintosh 7500">7500</a>/<a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh_8500" title="Power Macintosh 8500">8500</a>/<a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh_9500" title="Power Macintosh 9500">9500</a> <a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh" title="Power Macintosh">Power Macs</a>. Apple has since joined the industry standards groups to influence the future direction of technology standards such as <a href="/wiki/USB" title="USB">USB</a>, <a href="/wiki/Accelerated_Graphics_Port" title="Accelerated Graphics Port">AGP</a>, <a href="/wiki/HyperTransport" title="HyperTransport">HyperTransport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wi-Fi" title="Wi-Fi">Wi-Fi</a>, <a href="/wiki/NVM_Express" title="NVM Express">NVMe</a>, <a href="/wiki/PCI_Express" title="PCI Express">PCIe</a> and others in its products. <a href="/wiki/FireWire" class="mw-redirect" title="FireWire">FireWire</a> is an Apple-originated standard that was widely adopted across the industry after it was standardized as <a href="/wiki/IEEE_1394" title="IEEE 1394">IEEE 1394</a> and is a legally mandated port in all Cable TV boxes in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">&#91;380&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple has gradually expanded its efforts in getting its products into the Indian market. In July 2012, during a conference call with investors, CEO <a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a> said that he "[loves] India", but that Apple saw larger opportunities outside the region.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">&#91;381&#93;</a></sup> India's requirement that 30% of products sold be manufactured in the country was described as "really adds cost to getting product to market".<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">&#91;382&#93;</a></sup> In May 2016, Apple opened an iOS app development center in <a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a> and a maps development office for 4,000 staff in Hyderabad.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup> In March, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> reported that Apple would begin manufacturing iPhone models in India "over the next two months",<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">&#91;384&#93;</a></sup> and in May, the <i>Journal</i> wrote that an Apple manufacturer had begun production of <a href="/wiki/IPhone_SE_(1st_generation)" title="IPhone SE (1st generation)">iPhone SE</a> in the country,<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup> while Apple told <i><a href="/wiki/CNBC" title="CNBC">CNBC</a></i> that the manufacturing was for a "small number" of units.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">&#91;386&#93;</a></sup> In April 2019, Apple initiated manufacturing of iPhone 7 at its <a href="/wiki/Bengaluru" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengaluru">Bengaluru</a> facility, keeping in mind demand from local customers even as they seek more incentives from the government of India.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">&#91;387&#93;</a></sup> At the beginning of 2020, Tim Cook announced that Apple schedules the opening of its first physical outlet in India for 2021, while an online store is to be launched by the end of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">&#91;388&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/2022_COVID-19_protests_in_China" title="2022 COVID-19 protests in China">2022 COVID-19 protests in China</a>, Chinese <a href="/wiki/State-owned_enterprises_of_China" title="State-owned enterprises of China">state-owned</a> company <a href="/wiki/Wingtech" title="Wingtech">Wingtech</a> was reported by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> to gain an additional foothold in Apple's supply chain following protests at a Foxconn factory in the <a href="/wiki/Zhengzhou_Airport_Economy_Zone" title="Zhengzhou Airport Economy Zone">Zhengzhou Airport Economy Zone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Worker_organizations">Worker organizations</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple_and_unions" title="Apple and unions">Apple and unions</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097763485"><table class="box-Summarize plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><span typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/80px-Edit-clear.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="48" data-file-height="48" /></span></span></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span"><b>This section should include a better summary of, or be better summarized in <a href="/wiki/Apple_and_unions" title="Apple and unions">Apple and unions</a>.</b><span class="hide-when-compact"> See <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Summary_style" title="Wikipedia:Summary style">Wikipedia:Summary style</a> for information on how to  incorporate it into this article's main text, or the main text of another article.</span>  <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">January 2023</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In 2006, one complex of factories in <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a>, China that assembled the iPod and other items had over 200,000 workers living and working within it. Employees regularly worked more than 60 hours per week and made around $100 per month. A little over half of the workers' earnings was required to pay for rent and food from the company.<sup id="cite_ref-wpsweatshop_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wpsweatshop-392">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">&#91;391&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Apple immediately launched an investigation after the 2006 media report, and worked with their manufacturers to ensure acceptable working conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">&#91;392&#93;</a></sup> In 2007, Apple started yearly audits of all its suppliers regarding <a href="/wiki/Worker%27s_rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Worker&#39;s rights">worker's rights</a>, slowly raising standards and pruning suppliers that did not comply. Yearly progress reports have been published as of 2008<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup> In 2011, Apple admitted that its suppliers' child labor practices in China had worsened.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">&#91;394&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Foxconn_suicides" title="Foxconn suicides">Foxconn suicides</a> occurred between January and November 2010, when 18 <a href="/wiki/Foxconn" title="Foxconn">Foxconn</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh">富士康</span>) employees attempted <a href="/wiki/Suicide" title="Suicide">suicide</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-tian_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tian-397">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup> resulting in 14 deaths—the company was the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, for clients including Apple, at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-tian_397-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tian-397">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-scmpreport_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scmpreport-398">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-reuters3_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters3-399">&#91;397&#93;</a></sup> The suicides drew media attention, and employment practices at Foxconn were investigated by Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-WSJ-Foxconn_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WSJ-Foxconn-400">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup> Apple issued a public statement about the suicides, and company spokesperson Steven Dowling said:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1211633275">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 32px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote" style="font-size:100%"><p>[Apple is] saddened and upset by the recent suicides at Foxconn ... A team from Apple is independently evaluating the steps they are taking to address these tragic events and we will continue our ongoing inspections of the facilities where our products are made.<sup id="cite_ref-pledge_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pledge-401">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>The statement was released after the results from the company's probe into its suppliers' labor practices were published in early 2010. Foxconn was not specifically named in the report, but Apple identified a series of serious labor violations of labor laws, including Apple's own rules, and some child labor existed in a number of factories.<sup id="cite_ref-pledge_401-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pledge-401">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup> Apple committed to the implementation of changes following the suicides.<sup id="cite_ref-Fire_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fire-402">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Also in 2010, workers in China planned to sue iPhone contractors over poisoning by a cleaner used to clean LCD screens. One worker claimed that he and his coworkers had not been informed of possible occupational illnesses.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">&#91;401&#93;</a></sup> After a high suicide rate in a Foxconn facility in China making iPads and iPhones, albeit a lower rate than that of China as a whole,<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">&#91;402&#93;</a></sup> workers were forced to sign a legally binding document guaranteeing that they would not kill themselves.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup> Workers in factories producing Apple products have also been exposed to <a href="/wiki/Hexane" title="Hexane">hexane</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Neurotoxin" title="Neurotoxin">neurotoxin</a> that is a cheaper alternative than alcohol for cleaning the products.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A 2014 BBC investigation found excessive hours and other problems persisted, after Apple's promise to reform factory practice after the 2010 Foxconn suicides. The <a href="/wiki/Pegatron" title="Pegatron">Pegatron</a> factory was again the subject of review, as reporters gained access to the working conditions inside through recruitment as employees. The BBC maintained that the experiences of its reporters showed that labor violations were continuing as of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, but Apple publicly disagreed with the BBC and stated: "We are aware of no other company doing as much as Apple to ensure fair and safe working conditions".<sup id="cite_ref-Fire_402-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fire-402">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2014, the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Global_Labour_and_Human_Rights" title="Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights">Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights</a> published a report which documented inhumane conditions for the 15,000 workers at a Zhen Ding Technology factory in Shenzhen, China, which serves as a major supplier of circuit boards for Apple's iPhone and iPad. According to the report, workers are pressured into 65-hour work weeks which leaves them so exhausted that they often sleep during lunch breaks. They are also made to reside in "primitive, dark and filthy dorms" where they sleep "on plywood, with six to ten workers in each crowded room." Omnipresent security personnel also routinely harass and beat the workers.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2019, there were reports stating that some of Foxconn's managers had used rejected parts to build iPhones and that Apple was investigating the issue.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-2023_PC-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2023_PC_9-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1215172403"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.gartner.com/en/newsroom/press-releases/01-10-2024-gartner-says-worldwide-pc-shipments-increased-zero-point-three-percent-in-fourth-quarter-of-2023-but-declined-fourteen-point-eight-percent-for-the-year">"Gartner Says Worldwide PC Shipments Increased 0.3% in Fourth Quarter of 2023 but Declined 14.8% for the Year"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Gartner" title="Gartner">Gartner</a>. January 11, 2024. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20240111045024/https://www.gartner.com/en/newsroom/press-releases/01-10-2024-gartner-says-worldwide-pc-shipments-increased-zero-point-three-percent-in-fourth-quarter-of-2023-but-declined-fourteen-point-eight-percent-for-the-year">Archived</a> from the original on January 11, 2024<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-10">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1215172403"><cite id="CITEREFPorter2024" class="citation web cs1">Porter, Jon (January 16, 2024). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.theverge.com/2024/1/16/24039830/apple-bestselling-phone-manufacturer-2023-samsung-idc-canalys-research">"Apple tops Samsung for first time in global smartphone shipments"</a>. <i>The Verge</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20240117014152/https://www.theverge.com/2024/1/16/24039830/apple-bestselling-phone-manufacturer-2023-samsung-idc-canalys-research">Archived</a> from the original on January 17, 2024<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-VintageNews-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-VintageNews_22-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1215172403"><cite id="CITEREFBlazeski2017" class="citation news cs1">Blazeski, Goran (November 25, 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.thevintagenews.com/2017/11/25/apples-first-official-product-was-priced-at-666-66">"Apple-1, Steve Wozniak's hand-built creation, was Apple's first official product, priced at $666.66"</a>. <i>The Vintage News</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200726090158/https://www.thevintagenews.com/2017/11/25/apples-first-official-product-was-priced-at-666-66/">Archived</a> from the original on July 26, 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">.
